THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Brenda R. Babb, Appellant,
				v.
				The Estate of
      Charles L. Watson, and Eleanor G. Watson and Pamela Watson Fehlig, as
      Personal Representatives of the Estate of Charles L. Watson, and CLW
      Investments, Inc., d/b/a Salt Marsh Cove, and Wilbur M. McLamb, individually,
      Little River Campground, Inc., and Carl Meares, individually, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished No. 2008-UP-247
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 2, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brenda R. Babb, of Calabash, North Carolina, pro se, Appellant.
				Stephen V. Futeral, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondents.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Brenda R. Babb (Babb)
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order for the Respondents arguing (1) the statute
  of limitations expired before their declaratory judgment counterclaim was
  filed, (2) the counterclaim did not relate back to the date of the original
  pleadings, and (3) the circuit court erred in ruling on the Respondentsâ€™ waiver
  defense because it had been disposed of prior to trial by summary judgment.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
Facts
At an auction conducted by the United States Marshals Service in June 1991, Babb, Charles Watson, and Carl Meares submitted a
  successful bid of $400,000 for an 8.4 acre parcel of land known as Little River
  Campground (the Campground) in Horry County, South Carolina.Â  Babb, Watson and
  Meares each paid $25,000 earnest money to hold their interest, leaving a
  balance of $375,000.Â  The parties agreed to form a corporation in which the Campground
  would be the corporationâ€™s asset.Â  Babb, Watson and Meares would be
  shareholders with a one-third interest in the corporation.Â  In August, 1991,
  the parties filed articles of incorporation for Little River Campground
  Incorporated (LRCI).Â  Babbâ€™s husband, Mac Babb, was appointed president and
  Watson was Secretary and Treasurer.Â  In April 1995, Watson issued three LCRI
  stock certificates, one to each party, and mailed them to Mac Babb for his
  signature as president.Â  Babb is in possession of her stock certificate though
  the parties contest whether the certificates were ever satisfactorily signed
  and delivered before closing.Â  
Due
  to environmental cleanup efforts, the sale of the property was not closed until
  December 6, 1995, at which time Babb, Watson and Meares each paid $125,000.Â 
  Prior to closing, however, Babb instructed the closing attorney, John Martini
  (Martini), to deed to her a one-third undivided interest in the 8.4 acres.Â  It
  is undisputed that upon closing, LRCI was deeded a two-third undivided interest
  in the property and Babb was deeded an undivided interest in one-third.Â  
Babb
  contended that she became aware that 4.2 acres of land adjacent to the
  Campground was available for purchase.Â  In amended pleadings, she stated the
  parties discussed forming a new corporation in which to title this new acreage
  and any subsequently acquired real property.Â  The parties concede the acreage
  was purchased and titled to CLW Investments, a real estate investment company
  operated by respondents Watson and McLamb.Â  
On June
  24, 1997, Babb commenced a derivative suit against Watson, and McLamb
  concerning the purchase.[2] Â Respondents answered with general denials.Â  Babb filed an amended
  complaint on August 10, 1998, naming as plaintiffs LRCI; Mac Babb, as an
  officer and director of LRCI; and herself individually and as a shareholder.Â  The
  case was stricken from the roster pursuant to Rule 40(j), SCRCP, but restored
  by motion in May 1999.Â  Respondents filed an amended answer in April 2001.Â 
  This answer provided in part:

	
		
			2.
			To the extent that Plaintiffâ€™s Complaint infers 
			that Plaintiff Brenda Babb is shareholder in Little River 
			Campground, Inc., such allegation is denied and strict proof is 
			demanded thereof.
		
	

In addition to general
  admissions and denials, the answer asserted no agreement was reached concerning
  the purchase of the adjacent property.Â  It asserted the defenses of unclean
  hands, waiver by Babb of any legal or equitable interest in LRCI, and laches.Â 
  The answer additionally requested a 12(b)(6) dismissal.Â  Pursuant to
  Respondentsâ€™ motion, LRCI and Mac Babb were dismissed from the case on May 25,
  2001.Â  
In
  June 2001, Respondents filed and served an amended answer that included a
  counterclaim for slander of title.Â  A reply to the amended answer and
  counterclaim was filed July 26, 2001.Â  Regarding the counterclaim, Babb claimed
  Respondents failed to bring the counterclaim within the applicable statute of
  limitations, and asserted the additional defense of laches.
Respondents
  moved to transfer the suit to the non-jury roster and requested that any
  equitable shareholderâ€™s claim should be resolved prior to a jury trial on any
  remaining issues.Â  The order was granted with the circuit court finding:

	
		
			1)   
			The gravamen of Plaintiffâ€™s
  complaint is a shareholderâ€™s derivative suit filed on behalf of Little River
  Campground, Inc. against Defendants alleging they usurped a corporate
  opportunityâ€¦.
 
		
		
			2)
			That many, if not all, of the other claims asserted 
			by Plaintiffs have, as their basis, a claim that Defendants were 
			alleged required to acquire land on behalf of Little River 
			Campground, Inc. and that Defendants usurped a corporate 
			opportunity;
		
	

On
  July 26, 2002, Babb filed an amended reply to Respondentsâ€™ second amended
  answer and counterclaim.Â  In addition to a general denial, Babb reiterated the
  statute of limitations and laches defenses.Â  
The
  circuit court in Charleston County, on June 18, 2003, addressed several motions
  filed by the parties.Â  Relevant to this appeal, Babbâ€™s motion to amend and
  dismiss her claims as a shareholder in LRCI was granted.Â  
Babb
  moved for summary judgment on Respondentsâ€™ slander of title counterclaim and
  the defenses of unclean hands and waiver.Â  By an order filed December 29, 2003,
  summary judgment was granted to Babb on the slander of title counterclaim.Â  The
  circuit court acknowledged Babbâ€™s claims as a shareholder had been dismissed at
  her request.Â  The court stated:

	Because
  her damage claims as a shareholder have been dismissed, defendantsâ€™ affirmative
  defenses as to those claims should likewise be dismissed.Â  Therefore,
  plaintiff is hereby granted summary judgment on defendantsâ€™ defenses of unclean
  hands and waiver.

(emphasis added).
Respondents
  moved for a third amended answer and counterclaim in December 2003.Â Â  The
  answer added LRCI and shareholder Carl Meares as parties.Â  It repeated the same
  general admissions and denials contained in previous answers.Â  Pertinent to this
  appeal, as a defense and by way of a counterclaim, Respondents raised a
  declaratory judgment action.Â  In support, Respondents contend they are entitled
  to a court order declaring Babb (1) waived any legal or equitable interest in
  LRCI by request and receipt of an undivided one-third interest; (2) is barred
  from claiming interest by the unclean hands doctrine; and (3) is not a
  shareholder in LRCI.Â  
The circuit court
  granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to amend the answer and counterclaim and add
  parties on January 5, 2004.Â  The order stated:

	[I]t
  appears that the matters which Defendants seek to raise by amendment are matters
  which have been litigated by these parties for the past several years this
  action has been pending.Â  Under these circumstances, Plaintiff is not
  prejudiced by such amendment.

Babb
  filed her reply to the third amended answer and counterclaim on March 4, 2004.Â 
  In June 2004, the declaratory action was heard at a bench trial.Â  The sole
  issue was whether Babb was a shareholder in LRCI.Â  The circuit court ruled in
  favor of Respondents.Â  
Discussion 
Babb
  argues the circuit court erred by (1) hearing Respondentsâ€™ counterclaim because
  the statute of limitations had expired; (2) finding the counterclaim related
  back to the date of the original pleadings; and (3) ruling on Respondentsâ€™
  waiver defense because it had previously been dismissed by summary judgment.Â  We
  disagree.

	According to the discovery rule, the
  statute of limitations begins to run when a cause of action reasonably ought to
  have been discovered. The statute runs from the date the injured party either
  knows or should have known by the exercise of reasonable diligence that a cause
  of action arises from the wrongful conduct.

Hedgepath v. AT&T, 348 S.C. 340, 355-56, 559 S.E.2d 327, 336 (2001)
  (quoting Dean v. Ruscon, 321 S.C. 360, 468 S.E.2d 645 (1996)).Â  â€œThe
  exercise of reasonable diligence means simply that an injured party must act
  with some promptness where the facts and circumstances of an injury would put a
  person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his has
  been invaded or that some claim against another party might exist.â€Â  Wiggins
    v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 126, 442 S.E.2d 169 (1994).Â  The fact that an injured
  party may not comprehend the full extent of the damage is immaterial.Â  Dean
    v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 468 S.E.2d 645 (1996).Â  In State ex rel.
      Condon v. City of Columbia, 339 S.C. 8, 19, 528 S.E.2d 408, 414 (2000), our
  Supreme Court instructed:

	Statutes of limitations embody important public policy
  considerations in that they stimulate activity, punish negligence, and promote
  repose by giving security and stability to human affairs. Â One purpose of a
  statute of limitations is to relieve the courts of the burden of trying stale
  claims when a plaintiff has slept on his rights. Â Another purpose ... is to
  protect potential defendants from protracted fear of litigation.

Here, Babb asserts
  the statute of limitations began to run with the December 6, 1995 closing on
  the Campground. Â She contends Respondents knew or should have known she claimed
  a one-third interest in both LRCI and the Campground.Â  According to Babb, Respondentsâ€™
  declaratory judgment action was barred on December 5, 1998.Â  Respondents filed
  the action January 16, 2004.Â  
Respondents
  argue the counterclaim for declaratory judgment relates back to Babbâ€™s initial
  lawsuit pursuant to Rule 15(c), SCRCP.Â  Rule 15 provides in pertinent part:

	(c) Relation Back of Amendments. Whenever the claim or defense asserted in the amended
  pleading arose out of the conduct, transaction or occurrence set forth or
  attempted to be set forth in the original pleadings, the amendment relates back
  to the date of the original pleading.

â€œThe
  central requirement here is that the party defending against the new claim have
  sufficient notice of it, i.e., â€˜the new claim must be â€˜logically
  relatedâ€™ to the matters originally pleaded so that the defendant is not
  prejudiced by the new claim asserted after the statute of limitations has expired.â€™â€ Â Â Whitfield
    Constr. Co. v. Bank of Tokyo Trust Co., 338 S.C. 207, 223, 525 S.E.2d 888,
  897 (Ct. App. 1999) (quoting James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil
    Procedure 127 (2d ed.1996)) (emphasis in original).Â  

	In federal practice, the factors to determine whether or not a
  claim arose out of the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence set forth in
  the original pleading include: (1) whether the party defending against the new
  claim had notice of it; (2) whether the party seeking to add the new claim will
  rely on the same kind of evidence offered in support of the original claim to
  prove the new claim; and (3) whether unfair surprise to the defending party
  would result if the amendment were to relate back.

Id.Â  (citing James Wm. Moore, Mooreâ€™s
  Federal Practice Â§ 15.19[2]Â  (Daniel R. Coquillete et al eds., 3d
  1999)).
In Whitfield, the defendant bank asserted a counterclaim
  for abuse of process after the statute of limitations had run.Â  This court
  instructed, â€œ[t]he proper inquiryâ€¦ is whether [the defendant] had ever provided
  notice in any of its prior pleadings that it intended to allege such a
  counterclaim, not whether Whitfield should have anticipated that the
  counterclaim would follow as a result of his own actions.â€Â  Id. Â The
  defendantâ€™s first responsive pleading presented only general denials and
  certain defenses.Â  A first amended counterclaim added an unjust enrichment
  counterclaim and prayed for a set-off, but it was otherwise similar to the
  original answer.Â  Neither pleading suggested the plaintiff made improper use of
  process, and â€œ[w]ithout any indication in its prior responsive pleadings that Whitfield
  was to defend against such an allegation, we fail to see how [the defendant]
  had set forth, or even attempted to set forth, the conduct, transaction, or
  occurrence giving rise to a counterclaim for abuse of process.â€Â  Id. at 224, 525 S.E.2d at 897.Â  The court noted the lack of any serious dispute that
  the defendant knew or should have known it had an abuse of process counterclaim
  when the complaint was filed.Â  Id. at 224, 525 S.E.2d at 898.Â  â€œThe
  question of whether the amendment resulted in actual prejudice to Whitfield is
  not a factor in determining whether the counterclaim is barred by the statute
  of limitations.â€Â  Id. at 224-25, 525 S.E.2d at 898.Â  Accordingly, the
  counterclaim did not relate back.
Here,
  the circuit court judge inquired whether Respondents ever gave notice in prior
  pleadings of an intention to allege a counterclaim for a declaratory judgment
  that Babb was not a shareholder in LRCI.Â  He determined the first answer filed
  July 16, 1997, included only general denials and certain defenses.Â  But after
  Babb first asserted she was a shareholder in her amended complaint filed August
  10, 1998, Respondentsâ€™ amended answer in reply specifically denied Babb was a
  shareholder in LRCI.Â  The circuit judge found â€œ[u]nlike in Whitfield,
  the defendants in the instant case indicated in their prior responsive
  pleadings that the plaintiff was to defend against the allegation that she was
  not a shareholder of [LRCI].â€Â Â  Accordingly, the circuit judge concluded the
  declaratory judgment counterclaim â€œarose out of the conduct, transaction, or occurrence
  set forth or attempted to be set forth in the original pleading, the plaintiff
  had sufficient notice of the claim, and the claim is logically related to the
  matters originally pled.â€Â  
The
  circuit court judge further noted the issue had previously been decided by an
  order filed January 4, 2004, by a different circuit court judge.Â  There, Respondentsâ€™
  motion to amend their answer and assert the counterclaim was granted.Â  The
  judge granting the motion determined, â€œit appears that the matters which [Respondents]
  seek to raise by amendment are matters which have been litigated by these
  parties for the past several years this action has been pending.â€Â  Importantly,
  no motion to alter or amend the ruling has been made by either party, nor has
  there been a request to reconsider.Â  Thus, the judge issuing the declaratory
  judgment correctly acknowledged he had no right to reconsider the order of
  another circuit judge.Â  See Dinkins v. Robbins, 203 S.C. 199,
  202, 26 S.E.2d 689 (1943) (â€œthe prior order of one Circuit Judge may not be
  modified by the subsequent order of another Circuit Judge, except in cases
  where the right to do so has been reserved to the succeeding Judge, when it is
  allowed by rule or statute, or when the subsequent order does not substantially
  affect the ruling or decision represented by the previous order.â€)Â  
In
  their counterclaim, Respondents argued Babb â€œwaived any legal or equitable
  interest she had in [LRCI], inasmuch as she requested and received an undivided
  one-third interest in 8.4 acres (2.8 acres) that was to be titled, in its
  entirety, in the name of [LRCI].â€Â  â€œWaiver is a voluntary and intentional
  abandonment or relinquishment of a known right.â€Â  Murdock v. Murdock,
  338 S.C. 322, 333, 526 S.E.2d 241, 247 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Parker v.
    Parker, 313 S.C. 482, 443 S.E.2d 388 (1994)).Â  Waiver may be express or implied
  by a partyâ€™s conduct.Â  Parker, 313 S.C. at 487, 443 S.E.2d at 391.Â  Acts
  inconsistent with the continued assertion of a right may implicate waiver.Â  Provident
    Life and Acc. Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 478, 451 S.E.2d 924, 928
  (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œWhether a party is barred byâ€¦ waiver can only be determined
  in light of the circumstances of each case.â€Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas
    Horizontal Property Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 388 (1992).Â 
  Waiver is an affirmative defense and the party asserting it has the burden of
  proof.Â  Provident Life and Acc. Ins. Co., 317 S.C. at 478, 451 S.E.2d at
  928; Frady v. Smith, 247 S.C. 353, 147 S.E.2d 412 (1966).Â  â€œGenerally,
  the party claiming waiver must show that the party against whom waiver is
  asserted possessed, at the time, actual or constructive knowledge of his rights
  or of all the material facts upon which they depended.â€Â  Janasik, 307
  S.C. at 344, 415 S.E.2d at 387-88.
Babb
  argues Respondentsâ€™ use of waiver is an inappropriate offensive use of the
  doctrine.Â  See Janasik, 307 S.C. at 345, 415 S.E.2d at 388
  (waiver is protective only and not to be used as an offensive weapon).Â  However,
  the circuit court concluded the Respondents â€œasserted waiver to protect their
  purported investment, to shield [Babb] from claiming an interest in which they
  do not concede she has a right.â€Â  We agree.
Babb
  brought her shareholder status into contention when she brought a shareholder
  derivative action.Â  When Babb voluntarily dismissed her claims as a shareholder
  over Respondentsâ€™ objection, the record shows Respondents expressed to the
  court their desire that the order reflect their continued claims that Babb was
  not a shareholder.Â  Babb contends that because she had dismissed her
  shareholder claims, Respondents were without a cause of action requiring this
  defense.Â  However, as the circuit judge stated, Respondents only raised the
  declaratory judgment action upon the dismissal of her shareholder claims.Â  Â Â 
â€œThe Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act does not create substantive
  rights or duties; rather it authorizes an action to establish a partyâ€™s
  entitlement to a pre-existing right.â€Â  Harvey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t
    of Corrections, 338 S.C. 500, 527 S.E.2d 765 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Noisette v. Ismail, 299 S.C. 243, 247 n. 1, 384 S.E.2d 310, 312 n. 1
  (Ct. App. 1989), revâ€™d in part by 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-53-10 et. seq. (2005).Â  Respondentsâ€™ counterclaim
  seeking to establish their right to possess the shares of LRCI was authorized
  by the Declaratory Judgments Act.Â  
Respondents, however, carried the burden to prove Babb waived her
  interest in LRCI.Â  The parties agree LRCI was formed solely for the purpose of
  holding the 8.4 acres of land known as Little River Campground.Â  Articles of
  incorporation were filed with the Secretary of State in August, 1991.Â  Further,
  the parties agree Babb was deeded an undivided one-third interest in the Campground.Â 
  A review of the record leads this court to agree with the circuit court that
  Babb voluntarily and intentionally abandoned or relinquished any right to a one-third
  interest in LRCIâ€™s corporate shares.Â  
According to Mearesâ€™ testimony, at the time of LRCIâ€™s formation in
  1991, no stock certificates were issued.Â  Between 1991 and 1995, no shareholder
  agreement existed, and no formal meetings were held to take votes.Â  As of 1991,
  Meares agreed Babb was a shareholder.Â  Due to contamination issues, it took
  from 1991 to 1995 to close on the property.Â  Together with Mac Babb and the
  help of attorneys, Meares worked on the environmental cleanup.Â  He was involved
  with correspondence and phone calls, and attended numerous related meetings
  with Mac Babb.Â  Meares testified that he and Mac Babb volunteered their
  efforts, spent roughly the same time working on the cleanup, and had never had
  any agreement that the two would be compensated.Â  Further, he said he never had
  a conversation with Babb indicating she would receive more than a one-third
  interest in the Campground.Â  
On April 4, 1995, Watson sent to Babb and Mac Babb three
  promissory notes for $5000 to be executed by each investor, a proposed
  shareholder agreement, and stock certificates for Babb, Watson and Meares.Â  Although
  signed by Watson as secretary of LRCI, to be valid, the certificates required
  Mac Babbâ€™s signature as president.Â  The record indicates on May 17, 1995,
  Watson sent a revised shareholder agreement to Babb and Mac Babb and requested
  again that Mac Babb sign and return the stock certificates.Â  At trial, Jerry
  Fehlig, Watsonâ€™s son-in-law and current LRCI secretary, and Meares both
  testified to never having seen any stock certificates bearing both required
  signatures.Â  Whereas Respondents produced copies of certificates for Meares and
  Watson bearing only Watsonâ€™s signature, Babb introduced into evidence an
  original stock certificate bearing the signatures of Watson and Mac Babb.Â  Citing Ward v. Atlas Construction Company, Inc., 276 S.C. 346, 278 S.E.2d 621 (1981),
  the circuit court explained in its order mere possession of a stock certificate
  is not dispositive.
Respondents contend Babb and Mac Babb created the shareholder
  claim by Mac Babb signing the stock certificate after the closing on the Campground
  and the death of Watson.Â  Mac Babb stated in his deposition he did not remember
  the date he signed the certificates, but he knew it was â€œafter April the 26th of 1995.â€Â  At trial, Babb testified she saw Mac Babb sign the stock
  certificates in Watsonâ€™s office and believed this happened in early June.Â 
  However, in her earlier deposition Babb reported she did not know when Watson
  sent the certificates to Mac Babb, whether they were signed by him as president
  of LRCI, or if Mac Babb transmitted the certificates to the other
  shareholders.Â  Babb explained the differing testimony resulted from her
  reviewing her records and notes some time after being deposed.Â  The circuit
  court observed â€œeven if she was much better prepared for trial, the trial was
  in 2004, three years after the deposition and ten years removed from the events
  in question.â€
Meares and Fehlig said Babb first produced her stock certificate
  bearing both signatures during discovery in 2001 or 2002.Â  Both told the court
  the other stock certificates sent simultaneously to Mac Babb for his signature
  were never signed and returned.Â  Fehlig further testified at trial that his
  review of corporate records failed to disclose any agreements concerning Babbâ€™s
  shareholder claim in LRCI.Â  Fehlig found neither corporate records documenting
  Mac Babbâ€™s LRCI activities nor any documents or corporate resolutions professing
  to â€œgive awayâ€ interest in LRCI to Babb.Â  The record indicates no corporate
  bank account was established.Â  The $5000 promissory notes and a shareholdersâ€™
  agreement were never executed.Â  However, the circuit judge in his order
  concluded â€œeven if the circumstances surrounding the stock certificates seem
  suspicious, the defendants have not proven fraud on the part of the plaintiff
  in the procurement of the signed stock certificate.â€

	In his deposition, Mac Babb was asked:
	
		
			Q:
			Do you have any knowledge whether initially the 
			deed for Little River Campground at closing was going to be 
			deededâ€”the property was going to be deeded solely in the name of [LRCI]?
 
		
		
			A: 
			It was never intended for that to happen.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Neverâ€”from what point was it never intended.
 
		
		
			A: 
			Never intended.
		
	

However, the circuit judgeâ€™s order indicates a letter entered into
  evidence indicated on October 3, 1995, Mac Babb, as president, received a letter
  from the General Services Administration asking if Mac Babb to â€œ[p]lease
  confirm that [Mac Babb] still desire[d] to have the deed identify the grantee
  as [LRCI].â€Â  A second letter from the General Services Administration dated
  November 2, 1995, asked Mac Babb to again confirm whether he still wanted the
  deed to identify LRCI as the grantee.Â  On November 13, 1995, Brandon sent a
  letter and a copy of the deed to closing attorney Martini.Â  Brandon indicated
  the original deed would be â€œovernightedâ€ to Martini upon receipt of the
  checks.Â  
The
  record shows Babb entered evidence that on November 14, 1995, she delivered a
  letter to closing attorney Martini that included a cashierâ€™s check for $125,000
  representing the purchase of one-third of the Campground.Â  Babb further
  indicated to Martini:

	The deed should identify me as Grantee for my portion of this
  transaction in the following manner and should be confirmed with the [General
  Services Administration] prior to closing by your office:Â  Brenda Robinson
  Babb, a resident of Brunswick County, North Carolina, a One Third Undivided
  Interest[.]

At trial, Meares testified he received a phone call from Martini before the closing, and
  then phoned Mac Babb in response:

	After I received the call from [Martini], I called thisâ€”this was
  the night before we had to close the next day.Â  And if we didnâ€™t close, the US Marshal Service had already notified us that we would lose the property and our $25,000
  that we originally put down.Â  And so I got a hold of Mac and asked him why he
  was all of a sudden at the last minute taking his one-third interest outside
  the corporation.Â  And he said, well, I donâ€™t want to be out-moneyed, and we
  just donâ€™t feel comfortable being in the corporation.Â  He said that Brenda
  doesnâ€™t feel comfortable being in the corporation, so she wants to take her
  one-third interest outside the corporation.Â  

Meares reported there was never any conversation with Mac Babb or
  Babb discussing Babbâ€™s entitlement to more than the one-third interest outside
  the corporation.Â  As a result, Meares stated his understanding was that he and
  Watson would be the only shareholders in LRCI.Â  In a subsequent phone call to
  Martini, Meares told him:

	I told [Martini] that Mac just was not going to cooperate so we
  had no other choice but to go ahead and give [Babb] her one-third interest
  outside the corporation, and I didnâ€™t have any choice but to agree to that or
  lose the property.

Babb
  explained at trial that she believed the original agreement between the parties
  was that â€œeach would participate with a third.â€Â  She averred her understanding
  was based on conversations to which she was a party.Â  However, in her
  deposition she had previously stated, â€œI donâ€™t know what the original
  understanding was because I wasnâ€™t involved in those negotiations.â€Â  She then
  explained in her testimony:\

	
		
			A: 
			I did not hear what Mr. Meares,
  Mr. Watson, and Mr. Babb discussed at the auction because I was standing at the
  other side of the tent.Â  What I am referring to is what I heard at the later
  meeting.Â  
		
	

In
  September 1995, Babb said it was decided she would receive more out of the
  investment.Â  Babb testified she never gave up or waived her interest in the
  shares of LRCI.Â  She explained, had she done so, Mac Babb would not have been
  compensated for his services as president.Â  However, Babbâ€™s counsel argued at
  trial there was an additional agreement between the shareholders to compensate
  Mac Babb.Â  Babb told the court that Mac Babb agreed in 1991 to become the
  president on the condition he be compensated based on his performance, which
  included enhancing the value of the property.Â  
Over
  his ten years as president, Babb stated Mac Babb secured the tape from the
  auction, attended several meetings in Georgia and South Carolina addressing the
  contamination issue, secured estimates of the dock repair and obtained dock
  permits, and dealt with various zoning matters.Â  Over the ten year period, Babb
  estimated Mac Babb â€œworked close to 3,000 hours a year on this property.â€Â  The
  circuit judge in his order considered this approximation â€œa staggering amount
  of time that this court calls into question.â€
Babb
  contended a compensation agreement was reached in September 1995.Â  On direct
  examination, Babb was asked:

	
		
			Q:
			All right.  Letâ€™s go back, and you tell the 
			court how it is that you ended up with a deed of one-third interest 
			of the real estate and a stock certificate representing one-third of 
			the stock.
 
		
		
			A:
			[Mac Babbâ€™s] compensation was based on his 
			performance.  As a result of his performance, I was given a 
			one-third undivided interest in the property which represented 11 
			percent from Mr. Watson, 11 percent from Mr. Meares.Â  The reason that I was given a one-third
  undivided interest is if I was given additional stock I would have controlling
  interest in the corporation.â€
		
	

While
  on the stand, the judge asked Babb:

	
		
			Q:
			[I]s it your position, maâ€™am, you
  were paidâ€”you were compensated in this manner for services that you husband
  performed for the corporation?
 
		
		
			A:
			My husband was compensated and my husband gave me 
			the compensation.     
		
	

In its order, the
  circuit court noted:

	[Babb] testified that Meares agreed that she would receive
  one-third (1/3) of the real estate in addition to her stock.Â  However, [Babb]
  testified at trial that she never had a conversation with Meares about any
  agreement to give her more of an interest.Â  As indicated previously, Meares
  testified he never had a conversation with [Babb] whereby [she] would receive
  more than a one-third (1/3) share of Little River Campground.

In his
  deposition, Mac Babb said Babb is a shareholder in LRCI, and she additionally holds
  a one-third undivided interest in the 8.4 acre campground.Â  Respondentsâ€™
  counsel questioned him on this outcome:

	
		
			Q:
			How is it, if you have three shareholders and they 
			all put in approximately the same amount, she comes out with so much 
			more?
 
		
		
			A: 
			It happens all the time, sir.  It happens all 
			the time, sir.  It happens in most people that donâ€™t pay the 
			same.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Okay.  What exactlyâ€”so youâ€™re sayingâ€”what are 
			you saying?  Just out of the goodness of their heart Carl Meares or Mr. Watson just said, Here, take some extra acreage?
 
		
		
			A: 
			 That may have been what happened.
 
		
		
			â€¦
			
 
		
		
			Q: 
			[] I want to know what your personal understanding 
			is as to how that arrangement was reached.
 
		
		
			A:
			I donâ€™t know.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Does that seem fair to you, that everybody would 
			put---
 
		
		
			A: 
			It seems fair to me.
 
		
		
			â€¦
			
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Was there any additional consideration given by 
			[Babb] to get additional acreage such that while every party put in 
			an equal amount of money she got more acreage than they did?
 
		
		
			A: 
			It happens all the time.
 
		
		
			â€¦
 
			 
		
		
			Q:
			Explain to me how she ended up getting one-third 
			undivided interest when everybody put in the same amount.
 
		
		
			A: 
			It happened.  
		
	

After a thorough review of the record, this court agrees with the
  order of the circuit court judge.Â  Although Babb was at one time a shareholder
  in LRCI, Mearesâ€™ testimony that Babb took an undivided one-third interest in
  the real property in lieu of any interest in LRCI is a more credible
  interpretation of the circumstances surrounding the closing on the Campground
  and production of the deed than that offered by Babb. Â We find no credible testimony
  that Babb and Meares agreed she would receive more than a one-third share in
  the real estate as a means of compensating Mac Babb for his services as
  president.Â  Indeed, she told the court her husband was compensated and he gave
  the compensation to her.Â  However, the record indicates that at her deposition,
  Babb stated she did not know whether Mac Babb ever requested compensation.Â  Mac
  Babb never mentioned that a compensation agreement was reached or that compensation
  was received by him and given to Babb.Â  Rather, when asked whether any
  additional compensation supported Babbâ€™s one-third interest in LRCI, he simply
  answered â€œ[i]t happens all the time.â€
Despite Babbâ€™s argument that any phone call between Meares and Mac
  Babb was insufficient to establish relinquishment of her rights in LRCI, Mac
  Babb represented Babbâ€™s interest as her agent throughout the venture.Â 
  â€œApparent authority to do an act is created as to a third person by written or
  spoken words or any other conduct of the principal which, reasonably
  interpreted, causes the third person to believe the principal consents to have
  the act done on his behalf by the person purporting to act for him.â€Â  R&G
    Constr., Inc. v. LowCountry Regional Transp. Authority, 343 S.C. 424, 433,
  540 S.E.2d 113, 118 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Frasier v. Palmetto Homes,
  323 S.C. 240, 473 S.E.2d 865 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  The elements of apparent agency
  are: (1) purported principal consciously or impliedly represented another to be
  his agent; (2) third party reasonably relied on the representation; and (3) the
  third party detrimentally changed his or her position in reliance on the
  representation.Â  Id.Â  â€œWhen a principal, by any such acts or conduct,
  has knowingly caused or permitted another to appear to be his agent, either
  generally or for a particular purpose, he will be estopped to deny such agency
  to the injury of third persons who have in good faith and in the exercise of reasonable
  prudence dealt with the agent on the faith of such appearances.â€ Â Id. (citing Mortgage & Acceptance Corp. v. Stewart, 142 S.C. 375, 140
  S.E. 804 (1927).Â  Generally, agency is a question of fact and may be implied or
  inferred and proven circumstantially by the conduct of the purported agent
  showing a pretense of authority with the alleged agentâ€™s knowledge.Â  Id.
We find Mac Babb was an apparent agent of Babb with the authority
  to relinquish her interest in LRCI.Â  Mac Babb testified he â€œhad [] Babbâ€™s
  proxyâ€ in a certain situation, which suggests he was an agent to other matters.Â 
  Babb testified she was not involved in the original negotiations carried out at
  the auction and indicated she did not hear Watson, Mac Babb, and Meares
  conversing.Â  Yet, she became an investor despite her lack of involvement.Â 
  During this initial discussion concerning the purchase of the Campground and
  formation of LRCI, Babb permitted Mac Babb to represent her interests.Â  From
  this interaction, Respondents reasonably believed Mac Babb had the authority to
  negotiate on behalf of Babb.Â  Specifically, Meares negotiated with Mac Babb
  concerning Babbâ€™s relinquishment of her interest in LRCI in lieu of a one-third
  undivided interest in the real property.Â  He reasonably relied on Mac Babbâ€™s
  assertions in informing closing attorney Martini to deed Babbâ€™s interest
  outside the corporation.Â  Further, Babb ratified Mac Babbâ€™s conduct with her
  letter to Martini instructing, â€œ[t]he deed should identify me as Grantee for my
  portion of this transactionâ€¦.â€Â  
This Court finds the record demonstrates Babb had full knowledge
  of Mac Babbâ€™s actions concerning the relinquishment of her rights in LRCI.Â   Babb
  ratified Mac Babbâ€™s conduct by manifesting her intent to adopt her husbandâ€™s
  actions and accepting the benefits.Â  She requested and was deeded an undivided
  one-third interest in Little River Campground.Â  See Crowley v.
    Harvey & Battey, P.A., 327 S.C. 68, 488 S.E.2d 334 (1997); Anthony
      v. Padmar, Inc., 320 S.C. 424, 465 S.E.2d 737 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The record
  clearly demonstrates Babb ratified Mac Babbâ€™s actions taken on her behalf and
  their conduct established an agency relationship.
Through her own actions and those of her agent, Mac Babb, this
  Court affirms the circuit judgeâ€™s conclusion that Babb voluntarily and
  intentionally relinquished her right to a one-third interest in LRCI.
Respondentsâ€™ answer and counterclaim included the equitable
  defense of unclean hands.Â  The doctrine of unclean hands precludes a plaintiff
  from recovering in equity if he acted unfairly in a matter that is the subject
  of the litigation to the prejudice of the defendant.Â  First Union National
    Bank of South Carolina v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 511 S.E.2d 372 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Respondents have clearly raised credibility issues concerning Babbâ€™s
  claims. Â However, this court finds Respondents failed to meet their burden of
  proving Babb acted unfairly in a matter that is the subject of the litigation
  between the parties sufficient to demonstrate â€œunclean hands.â€Â  We decline to
  apply the doctrine of unclean hands to the instant dispute.
Conclusion
Respondentsâ€™ counterclaim for a declaratory judgment that Babb was
  not a shareholder of LRCI was determined in the January 4, 2004, circuit court
  order finding it related back to matters originally pleaded and was not barred
  by the statute of limitations.
Respondents proved by a preponderance of the evidence that Babb
  voluntarily and intentionally relinquished her right to a one-third interest in
  the shares of LRCI in return for an undivided one-third interest in the 8.4
  acres known as Little River Campground. Therefore, the order of the circuit
  court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Charles Watson died in 1998 and this litigation has
  proceeded with the Estate of Charles L. Watson in his place.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Herbert Lee
      Bell, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Sumter County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-249
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 7, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Lanelle C. Durant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
  C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Herbert Lee Bell (Bell) appeals his
  conviction of trafficking in crack cocaine in an amount of more than two
  hundred grams but less than four hundred grams.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In
  late 2003, police obtained information about possible illegal drug activity in
  a trailer at 5595 Panola Road (â€œ5595â€) in Pinewood, in Sumter County.Â  Based on this information, the police sent a confidential informant wearing a wire to
  5595 on November 12 to purchase drugs. Â The informant purchased a quantity of
  crack cocaine (crack) from Reggie Robinson (Robinson).Â  The next day, an
  informant returned to 5595 and purchased another quantity of crack from
  Alexander Lewis (Lewis).Â  On November 20, the informant made another purchase
  of crack in 5595 from Robinson.Â  On November 25, the informant purchased more
  crack inside 5595 from Robinson.Â  
As
  a result of their investigation and the prior buys, the police obtained a
  search warrant for 5595 on November 26.Â  Before the warrant was executed, the
  police sent the informant back on December 4 to confirm the presence of drugs.Â 
  The informant went to 5595 in the morning, but there was no answer at the
  door.Â  The informant returned to the car where the police were waiting.Â  As
  they drove off down the road, Lewis walked out of another residence across the
  street at 5650 Panola Road (â€œ5650â€).Â  The informant got out of the car and
  talked with Lewis on the driveway of 5595.Â  Lewis told the informant to return
  at another time.Â  The informant returned to 5595 around eleven oâ€™clock, but
  again nobody was home.Â  Lewis came out of 5650 and told him to return at two
  oâ€™clock.Â  Around two oâ€™clock, the informant returned and purchased crack inside
  5595 from Lewis.Â  
A
  few hours later, the police executed the search warrant for 5595.Â  Lewis was
  seized inside the trailer and Robinson was apprehended as he tried to flee out
  the back door.Â  The police subsequently set up a reverse-sting and arrested
  numerous individuals who came to 5595 to purchase drugs.Â  They soon ran out of
  space to park the buyersâ€™ cars, so they ceased the operation.Â  
During
  the search of 5595, the police found a chair by the window near the door.Â 
  There was a small sliding match box on the window sill with crack inside.Â  A
  walkie-talkie was near the chair.Â  An aspirin bottle with crack and a jar of
  crack were seized in a bedroom.Â  There was a marijuana pipe in the bedroom with
  trace amounts of crack in it.Â  The total weight of the crack from 5595 was
  74.32 grams.Â  There was no furniture in the trailer other than the chair near
  the door and a mattress on the floor of the bedroom.Â  The bathroom was not
  functional.Â  Officer Angela Barger testified the trailer â€œdoesnâ€™t look like
  itâ€™s actually a lived in residence.Â  It just appears to be used solely for the
  purpose of narcotics.â€Â  An electric bill under the name â€œRacheka Michelle Bellâ€
  was found in the kitchen.Â  An appointment card and a medical receipt for Lewis
  were found in the kitchen.Â  A cash ticket for Bell from a furniture store for a
  roll-away bed was also found in the kitchen.
While
  the police were at 5595, other officers proceeded to 5650 to investigate.Â  Bell answered the door.Â  He agreed to accompany them across the street to 5595.Â  The
  police subsequently obtained a search warrant for 5650.
Pursuant
  to the search of 5650, the police seized a chair by the window in the living
  room with a clear view of 5595.Â  There was no other furniture inside except for
  a television and a video game system.Â  They found a scanner, binoculars, and a
  walkie-talkie nearby.Â  The kitchen had no dishes, food, or anything which
  indicated somebody lived in the residence.Â  The police discovered a half-gallon
  mason jar in the dishwasher in the kitchen, â€œone third to one half fullâ€ of
  crack.Â  The jar contained 227.03 grams of crack.Â  There were also assorted
  glassware and paraphernalia inside the dishwasher used to make crack.Â  There
  was crack residue on the items.Â  The walkie-talkies at 5650 and 5595 were set
  to the same channel.Â  The police found an insurance card for Bell in a drawer
  in the kitchen.Â  An application for pretrial intervention for Robinson was also
  inside the drawer.Â  Rental agreements for 5595 to Alexander Lewis and for 5650
  to â€œMichael Lewis,â€ dated November 1, 2003, were found in the living room.Â  An
  electric bill to Michael Lewis was found in a bedroom.Â  The mason jar found in
  5650 was dusted for fingerprints.Â  Robinson and Bellâ€™s fingerprints were found
  on it.Â  
Bell was served with arrest warrants for manufacturing
  crack and trafficking in crack on December 5, 2003.Â  Bell was released on a
  $70,000 surety bond, and he signed a bond sheet wherein under the heading
  â€œACKNOWLEDGEMENT BY THE DEFENDANT,â€ it indicates: â€œI understand and have been
  informed that I have a right and obligation to be present at trial, and should
  I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed in my absence.â€Â  
On
  February 19, 2004, the Sumter County Grand Jury indicted Bell on trafficking in
  crack cocaine in an amount of more than twenty-eight grams but less than one
  hundred grams and for trafficking in crack cocaine more than two hundred grams
  but less than four hundred grams.Â  On March 7, 2006, circuit court Judge
  Clifton Newman proceeded to trial with a jury against Bell on the trafficking
  charge of more than two hundred grams but less than four hundred grams.Â  Bellâ€™s attorney was present and ready for trial, but Bell was not in attendance at the
  trial.Â  The bailiff called his name from the courthouse step three times, but Bell did not respond and present himself for trial.Â  The two-day trial proceeded in Bellâ€™s absence.
Detective
  Allen Dailey explained the amount of crack seized from the mason jar in 5650
  â€œis solely something you would find with a seller, itâ€™s quite a bit of money.â€Â 
  Dailey testified the crack was â€œfreshly cutâ€ for sale.Â  Deputy Trevor Brown
  testified the police â€œhardly everâ€ find that much crack at one location.Â  Brown
  further said it was not uncommon for drug dealers to store drugs at one
  location and then sell them from another location.
Mack
  McLeod testified he owned both properties.Â  He recalled that shortly before Bellâ€™s arrest, Bell wanted to purchase 5650.Â  He paid rent in cash for it in November.Â 
  McLeod said 5595 was rented out by his father (since deceased), but he thought
  Lewis rented it.Â  
Alexander
  Lewis testified for the State.Â  Lewis testified he moved to 5595 with Bell, who is his nephew.Â  He stated Bell paid the rent.Â  Lewis said his brother Michael
  and Robinson also stayed with them on occasion.Â  Lewis testified he sold drugs from
  the trailer.Â  Lewis said the crack was kept in the jar seized by the police.Â 
  Lewis claimed he would go through a jar of crack â€œsometimes two times a day.â€Â 
  Lewis testified he got the crack from Bell and sold it for him.Â  In return,
  Lewis got crack for his personal use.Â  Lewis said Bell produced the crack in
  5595 and 5650.Â  He stated that Bell had moved to 5650.
Robinson
  also testified for the State.Â  Robinson said he stayed at 5595 â€œoff and on.â€Â 
  He and Bell were longtime friends.Â  Robinson testified Bell paid the rent and
  was there â€œall the time.â€Â  He said Alexander and Michael Lewis also stayed
  there.Â  Robinson said he sold drugs from 5595 for Bell.Â  Robinson testified Bell provided the crack and put it in the jars to sell.Â  He said a jar of crack would last
  â€œabout a week, two weeks.â€Â  Robinson gave Bell the money from the sales.Â 
  Robinson also testified Bell produced the crack in 5595 and 5650 and they used
  the walkie-talkies to communicate between the residences.Â  
The
  jury found Bell guilty, and Judge Newman issued a sentence but sealed it until Bell was present.Â  On June 7, 2006, Judge Steven H. John unsealed the sentence in Bellâ€™s presence and sentenced Bell to twenty-five years and a fine of $100,000.Â  Bellâ€™s attorney filed a notice of appeal on June 8, 2006.
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			Did the trial court err in proceeding with Bellâ€™s 
			trial in his absence?
 
		
		
			2. 
			Did the trial court err in not granting a mistrial 
			when the State failed to provide their expertâ€™s fingerprint report?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State
    v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We are
  bound by the trial court's factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 388, 577 S.E.2d at 500-01. 
On
  review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his
  discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State
    v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 224, 625 S.E.2d 239, 241-242 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  An
  abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error
  of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State
    v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In order for an
  error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  See State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); see
    also State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995).
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Trial in absentia
Bell argues the trial court erred by proceeding with his
  trial in his absence because he alleges the State failed to prove he had notice
  that his trial would proceed in his absence.Â  We disagree.
Bell signed a bond sheet on December 5, 2003, wherein
  under the heading â€œACKNOWLEDGEMENT BY THE DEFENDANT,â€ it indicates: â€œI
  understand and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to be
  present at trial, and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed
  in my absence.â€Â  
At
  trial, defense counsel admitted Bell was informed the Friday before that the
  case was going to be tried. Â He did not know where Bell was at the time of the
  trial.Â  Defense counsel then attempted to explain Bellâ€™s failure to appear.Â  He
  noted Bell had been given prior notices of trial and he appeared for trial and
  roll call during several terms of court during the past two years.Â  He surmised
  there were no assurances it would be different this time.Â  He stated â€œhow much
  assurance can an individual know that their case is actually going to trial if
  they have been told 2 or 3 times in the past that itâ€™s going for trial.Â  They
  show up, and it doesnâ€™t.Â  So itâ€™s like crying wolf . . . .â€Â  Defense counsel
  also said Bell had to work and Bell recently told him that he may take a job in
  New Orleans.
Bellâ€™s name was then called three times from the
  courthouse steps, but he did not respond.Â  Bell was thereafter tried in his
  absence.Â  
To
  preserve an issue for review there must be a contemporaneous objection that is
  ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 476
  S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996).Â  The objection should be addressed to the trial judge
  in a sufficiently specific manner that brings attention to the exact error.Â  State
    v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 548 S.E.2d 213, 216 (2001); State v.
      Funderburk, 367 S.C. 236, 625 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  If a party
  fails to properly object, the party is procedurally barred from raising the
  issue on appeal.Â  State v. Pauling, 322 S.C. 95, 470 S.E.2d 106, 109
  (1996); see State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 526 S.E.2d 228 (2000) (party
  may not argue one ground at trial and an alternative ground on appeal); State
    v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 440 S.E.2d 869 (1994) (to preserve error for
  appeallate review, a defendant must make a contemporaneous objection on a
  specific ground); McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327,
  479 S.E.2d 67, 76 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting the appellant failed to â€œpoint to
  specific objections and rulingsâ€ as required by the South Carolina Appellate
  Court Rules, thus leaving the court to â€œâ€˜grope in the darkâ€™ concerning the
  specific allegations of errorâ€); see also State v. Bray, 342 S.C.
  23, 535 S.E.2d 636 (2000) (it is error for an appellate court to consider
  issues not raised to it).
Although
  Bellâ€™s counsel objected to the trial in Bellâ€™s absence, he did not
  specifically object on the ground that Bell was not adequately warned the trial
  would proceed in his absence if he failed to appear.Â  Instead, defense counsel
  merely attempted to mitigate Bellâ€™s failure to appear, although he admitted Bell had notice of the trial.Â  Because there was no objection to the trial in Bellâ€™s absence on the ground alleged on appeal, the issue is not preserved for appellate
  review.
Bellâ€™s argument also fails on the merits.Â  Although the
  Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution guarantees the right of an
  accused to be present at every stage of his trial, this right may be waived.Â  State
    v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711 (1987); Ellis v. State,
  267 S.C. 257, 227 S.E.2d 304, 605 (1976).Â  Rule 16 of the South Carolina Rules
  of Criminal Procedure provides:

	[A]
  person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his
  right to be present and may be tried in his absence upon a finding by the court
  that such person has received notice of his right to be present and that a
  warning was given that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a failure to
  attend the court.

However,
  a waiver of such an important right is permitted only in limited
  circumstances.Â  Aiken v. Koontz, 368 S.C. 542, 629 S.E.2d 686, 689 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Therefore, before a defendant may be tried in absentia, the trial judge
  must determine a defendant voluntarily waived his right to be present at trial,
  making findings of fact on the record the defendant (1) received notice of his
  right to be present and (2) was warned the trial would proceed in his absence.Â  Id.
It
  is well-settled a bond form that provides notice that a defendant can be tried
  in absentia may serve as the requisite notice.Â  State v. Goode, 299 S.C.
  479, 385 S.E.2d 844, 846 (1989); State v. Fairey, 374 S.C. 92, 646
  S.E.2d 445, 449-50 (Ct. App. 2007); Koontz, 629 S.E.2d at 689-90.
In Koontz, the defendant was arrested for driving with a suspended license,
  and when he posted bond the day after arrest, he was provided an order
  specifying methods and conditions of release.Â  Id., 629 S.E.2d at 689.Â Â 
  The defendant also signed a form entitled â€œAcknowledgment by Defendant,â€ which
  read â€œI understand and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to
  be present at trial and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will
  proceed in my absence.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, this Court held Koontz was warned a
  failure to appear would result in a trial in his absence and he understood the
  warning and obligation by signing the acknowledgment.Â  
In Fairy, the defendant signed a similar bond sheet in 1998.Â  His original
  indictment was dismissed, but he was indicted for the same crime in 2001, and
  the 1998 bond was reinstated in 2002 by court order.Â  This Court held the 1998
  bond was in effect and thereby served as notice to the defendant that he would
  be tried in his absence if he failed to appear.
In
  the present case, Bell admits he signed the bond two years before his trial and
  shortly after his arrest.Â  Bell contends he â€œdid not know whether he was going
  to have a trial,â€ because the case was called for trial several times before
  and it did not go to trial.Â  Bell argues he appeared at prior times and his
  having to appear at every term of court interfered with his ability to hold a
  steady job.Â  Bell notes defense counsel did not state that he informed him the
  trial would proceed without him.Â  Bell states there was no evidence he read the
  bond form when he signed it or even that he could read.Â  His arguments are
  without merit.Â  
Notwithstanding
  the outcome of the prior roll calls in this case, Bell appeared as required.Â 
  Clearly, he demonstrated knowledge of his obligation to appear under the terms
  of the bond.Â  Bellâ€™s decision on this particular occasion to ignore the notice
  of trial, simply because he thought the outcome would be similar, does not
  excuse his failure to appear.Â  As in Fairey and Koontz, Bellâ€™s signature on the acknowledgment served as a warning he would be tried in his absence
  if and when his case was called for trial and he failed to appear.Â  Bell clearly understood such a warning and waived his right to be present.Â  Bellâ€™s other arguments go to the credibility of the evidence.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s findings
  were supported by the record and should not be disturbed.Â  
II.Â  Stateâ€™s
  fingerprint expert
Bell argues the trial court erred in not granting a
  mistrial when the State failed to provide the fingerprint report.Â  Bell contends he was prejudiced because he was unable to cross-examine the expert
  thoroughly or appropriately without the report and the defense did not have the
  opportunity to hire its own expert to examine the report.Â  We disagree.Â  
SLED
  Agent Edward Porter was qualified as an expert in fingerprint analysis and
  comparison.Â  Porter testified he received the backers from the mason jar.Â  At
  this point, defense counsel requested a â€œbrief side bar,â€ and counsel conferred
  with the trial judge.Â  Porter then testified he compared the fingerprints
  lifted from the mason jar with known fingerprints of Bell, Robinson, and
  Lewis.Â  Porter was able to match one of Bellâ€™s fingerprints on the jar and two
  of Robinsonâ€™s fingerprints.Â  On cross-examination, Porter testified he sent a
  report of his findings to law enforcement.
After
  the State rested its case four witnesses later, defense counsel requested a
  mistrial.Â  He argued he had not previously received the report despite his
  pretrial discovery request.Â  Defense counsel said Bell was prejudiced by not
  having the report, because counsel could not use it in cross-examination and he
  did not have the opportunity to hire an expert to examine the report.Â  
The
  trial judge denied the mistrial.Â  He initially noted that although â€œwe had a
  side bar,â€ there was â€œno objectionâ€ to Porterâ€™s testimony.Â  The trial judge
  further determined the failure to turn over the report was harmless because the
  defense was not surprised.Â  He noted defense counsel made a pretrial motion to
  suppress testimony about fingerprints.Â  
This
  issue is not properly preserved.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, a
  contemporaneous objection must be made when the evidence is offered.Â  See State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 498 S.E.2d 642, 644 n.3 (1998) (â€œUnless
  an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling
  made, the issue is not preserved for review.â€); State v. Johnson, 324
  S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996) (â€œAppellant made no contemporaneous
  objection at trial and did not raise this issue at any point during trial.Â 
  Consequently, this issue is not preserved for review.â€).Â  It well-settled a
  failure to contemporaneously object to the introduction of evidence claimed to
  be prejudicial cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.Â  State
    v. Lynn, 277 S.C. 222, 284 S.E.2d 786 (1981); State v. Moultrie, 316
  S.C. 547, 451 S.E.2d 34 (Ct. App. 1994); State v. Wilkins, 310 S.C. 81,
  425 S.E.2d 68 (Ct. App. 1992); see also State v. Curtis, 356 S.C.
  622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004) (a contemporaneous objection is required to preserve
  error for appellate review); State v. Atchison, 268 S.C. 588, 235 S.E.2d
  294 (1977) (if a party fails to make a proper contemporaneous objection to the
  admission of evidence, he cannot later raise the issue by a motion for a
  mistrial).Â  
Although
  Bell requested a â€œside barâ€ during the testimony of the Stateâ€™s fingerprint
  expert, the trial judge clearly noted there was no objection made at the time
  of the admission of the fingerprint evidence.Â  An objection was not made until
  the close of the Stateâ€™s case four witnesses later when Bell moved for a
  mistrial.Â  Bellâ€™s objection was untimely.Â  
Assuming
  arguendo that defense counsel timely objected to the Stateâ€™s fingerprint expert
  off-the-record, he was nevertheless required to immediately set forth the
  ground for the objection on the record to preserve it for appellate review.Â 
  His failure to do so here precludes review.Â  See York v. Conway Ford,
    Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997) (an objection made in an
  off-the-record conference but not placed on the record does not preserve the
  issue for appellate review); Hundley v. Rite Aid of S.C., Inc., 339 S.C.
  285, 529 S.E.2d 45, 57 (Ct. App. 2000) (motions must be made on the record to
  be preserved for review by an appellate court).
In
  any event, Bellâ€™s argument is without merit.Â  â€œâ€˜The power of a court to declare
  a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest caution under urgent
  circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causesâ€™ stated into the record by
  the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856, 862 (Ct. App. 2002); see also State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999) (a mistrial should only be granted in cases of manifest necessity and with
  the greatest caution for very plain and obvious reasons).Â  The granting of a
  motion for a mistrial is an extreme measure which should be taken only where an
  incident is so grievous the prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999); State v. Adams,
  354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).
A
  mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant
  must show both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a
  mistrial.Â  Simmons, 573 S.E.2d at 862; see also State v.
    Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (a mistrial should not be
  granted unless absolutely necessary; to receive a mistrial, a defendant must
  show error and resulting prejudice).Â  â€œThe less than lucid test is therefore
  declared to be whether the mistrial was dictated by manifest necessity or the
  ends of public justice.â€Â  State v. Prince, 279 S.C. 30, 301 S.E.2d 471,
  472 (1983).Â  â€œWhether a mistrial is manifestly necessary is a fact specific
  inquiry.â€Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000).
The
  decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the
  trial judge. Â State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 575 S.E.2d 77 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s decision will not be overturned on appeal absent an
  abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Harris, 340
  S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000); State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d
  63 (1998); see also State v. Arnold, 266 S.C. 153, 157, 221
  S.E.2d 867, 868 (1976) (the general rule of this state is that â€œthe ordering
  of, or refusal of a motion for mistrial is within the discretion of the trial
  judge and such discretion will not be overturned in the absence of abuse thereof
  amounting to an error of lawâ€).Â  
Rule
  5 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure governs the disclosure of
  evidence in criminal cases.Â  Applicable in this case are those provisions of
  Rule 5 which require the disclosure of certain documents, tangible objects, and
  reports of examinations and tests, that are within the possession, custody or
  control of the prosecution, and which are material to the preparation of the
  defendantâ€™s defense or are intended for use by the prosecution as evidence in
  its case-in-chief.Â  Rules 5(a)(1)(C) & (a)(1)(D), SCRCrimP.Â  Evidence is
  deemed material â€œonly if there is a reasonable probability that, had the
  evidence been disclosed to the defense, the result of the proceeding would have
  been different.â€Â  State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 471 S.E.2d 689, 693
  (1996); see also State v. Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 503 S.E.2d 214,
  220 (Ct. App. 1998) (definition of â€œmaterialâ€ for purposes of Rule 5 is the
  same as definition used in the Brady context), affâ€™d, 337 S.C.
  617, 524 S.E.2d 837 (1999).Â  Any omission â€œmust be evaluated in the context of
  the entire record.â€Â  State v. Wilkins, 310 S.C. 81, 425 S.E.2d 68, 70 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Absent a showing of prejudice suffered by the defendant, such that he is
  deprived of a fair trial, reversal is not required.Â  State v. Trotter,
  322 S.C. 537, 473 S.E.2d 452 (1996).
Even
  if the State failed to comply with Bellâ€™s Rule 5 request, the trial judge had
  the discretion to provide a proper remedy.Â  The exercise of this discretion
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v.
    Scipio, 283 S.C. 124, 322 S.E.2d 15 (1984); State v. Davis, 309 S.C.
  56, 419 S.E.2d 820 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  It is well-settled that if a party fails
  to comply with the rule, the court â€œmay order such party to permit the
  discovery or inspection, grant a continuance, or prohibit the party from
  introducing evidence not disclosed, or it may enter such other order as it
  deems just under the circumstances.â€Â  Rule 5(d)(2); see State v. Salisbury, 330 S.C. 250, 498 S.E.2d 655 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d as modified, 343
  S.C. 520, 541 S.E.2d 247 (2001).
However,
  this Court need not determine here whether the report in question should have
  been disclosed, since the trial judge properly determined Bell showed no
  prejudice.Â  The record clearly shows defense counsel was aware of the
  fingerprint evidence, as indicated by his pretrial motion to suppress it as the
  â€œfruitâ€ of an illegal arrest.Â  At no time, however, did the defense request a
  continuance or a recess to review the written report or to obtain other experts
  to refute the findings once it was disclosed.Â  See State v. Davis,
  309 S.C. 56, 419 S.E.2d 820 (Ct. App. 1992) (trial judgeâ€™s denial of the suppression
  of defendantâ€™s oral statements because the statements were not disclosed in a
  timely manner was upheld where the defendant did not request a continuance or
  recess to review the prosecutionâ€™s file); see also State v. Mitchell,
  330 S.C. 189, 498 S.E.2d 642 (1998) (issue not preserved when defense counsel
  indicated he might need a recess but never actually requested one).Â  Defense
  counsel was further able to thoroughly cross-examine the Stateâ€™s fingerprint
  expert.Â  Bell has failed to demonstrate there is a reasonable probability the
  result would have been different had the report been disclosed to him earlier.Â 
  There was no prejudice and Bell was not deprived of a fair trial.Â  There was no
  abuse of discretion in the denial of a mistrial motion.Â  Davis, 419
  S.E.2d at 825; see State v. Thompson, 276 S.C. 616, 281 S.E.2d
  216 (1981) (the Stateâ€™s failure to disclose does not warrant reversal unless
  the defendant is deprived of a fair trial).
CONCLUSION
The
  trial court did not err in proceeding with Bellâ€™s trial in his absence and in
  not granting a mistrial when the state failed to provide their expertâ€™s
  fingerprint report.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James W.
      Ratliff, III, DVM, Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, South Carolina Board of
      Veterinary Medical Examiners, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Administrative Law Court 
Â Carolyn C. Matthews, Administrative Law
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-250
Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 7,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Kenneth P.
  Woodington, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				James W. Ratliff,
  III, DVM, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  James W. Ratliff, III, DVM, petitioned the Administrative Law Court (ALC),
  appealing the order of the South Carolina State Board of Veterinary Medical
  Examiners (the Board).Â  The ALC reversed the Boardâ€™s order.Â  The Board
  appeals.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
Dr.
  Ratliff practiced veterinary medicine at the Pet Vac Express in the Greenville area.Â  Ratliff operated Pet Vac Expressâ€™ mobile veterinary clinic on Saturdays.Â 
  The Board held a hearing based on a report from a member of the public against three
  veterinarians, including Ratliff.Â  The Board filed a Complaint against the
  veterinarians, alleging, inter alia, the veterinarians failed to ensure that
  vaccines were properly maintained.Â  
After
  a hearing, the Board concluded Ratliff violated South Carolina Code Section
  40-69-140(12) by not adequately ensuring the vaccines were properly acquired
  and/or maintained.[2]Â 
  The Board issued a public reprimand and ordered Ratliff to pay a civil penalty
  of $250.Â  Ratliff appealed to the ALC.Â  On appeal, the ALJ found no substantial
  evidence to support the Boardâ€™s order and reversed.Â  The Board appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) governs
  contested proceedings before the Board.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 40-1-160 (2001) & 40-69-160
  (Supp. 2007).Â  The standard for judicial review, after an exhaustion of administrative remedies, is also governed by
  the APA. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380
  (Supp. 2007). Â Pursuant
  to the APA, a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision which is either affected by error of law or clearly erroneous
  in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence in the record.
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(Supp. 2007).Â  Review by an administrative law
  judge, heard in the appellate jurisdiction of the ALC, is governed by this
  standard.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(B)(Supp. 2007).Â  This court, on appeal
  from the ALC in its appellate capacity, applies the same standard of review.Â  See Dorman v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 164, 565
  S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App. 2002) (defining scope of review of second appellate
  review).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Board argues
  the ALJ erred in reversing its findings against Ratliff.Â  We agree.
Section 40-69-140(12)
  of the South Carolina Code enables the Board to reprimand a veterinarian for
  â€œengaging in conduct determined by the board to be incompetent or negligent in
  the practice of veterinary medicine.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-69-140(12) (2006)
  (amended by 2006 Act No. 294, Â§ 1, eff. May 31, 2006).[3]Â 
  Regulation 120-7.8(c) governs the practice of veterinary medicine relating to
  vaccines and requires that â€œ[t]emperature control shall be maintained for all
  drugs and biologics.â€Â  S.C. Code Reg. 120-7.8(c) (Rev. 1997).
We find substantial
  evidence to support the Boardâ€™s sanction
  against Ratliff.Â  Ratliff testified that
  he and Tabor â€œpretty muchâ€ knew when the vaccines would arrive based on the
  order date.Â  However, the evidence also indicates the vaccines were sent to a postal delivery site and
  remained there until Tabor took them to her home.Â  At best, the delivery site
  offered only an interior location out of the elements, and there is no evidence
  indicating such an environment would provide the necessary temperature control required
  by Regulation 120-7.8(c).Â  Based on the
  limited record[4] and our limited standard of review in APA cases, we find the ALJ erred in
  reversing the Boardâ€™s findings.Â  Accordingly, the order on appeal is
REVERSED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1]  We decide this case without oral
  argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  The Board dismissed the complaint
  against one of the veterinarians and made findings similar to those made
  against Ratliff as to the third veterinarian. 
[3]  The Board relied on the prior version of
  the code, section 40-69-140(12) (amended by 2006 Act No. 294, Â§ 1, eff. May 31,
  2006).Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-690-110 (12) (2007).
[4]  The Record on Appeal is limited to
  excerpts from the transcript of the proceeding before the Board, and Ratliff failed
  to file a respondentâ€™s brief with this Court.
