THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Lee Pye, Appellant,
				v.
				Mary B. Holmes,
      Charleston County Magistrate, and Charleston County, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-251
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 7, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Bonnie Travaglio Hunt, of Mt. Pleasant, and Holly Palmer Beeson,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				James A. Stuckey and Martinique M. Coval, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is an appeal of an order finding Lee Pyeâ€™s motion for a jury trial on her
  action against a Charleston County magistrate, Mary B. Holmes, and Charleston
  County was untimely made.Â  We affirm.[1]
On
  appeal, Pye contends the circuit court erred by (1) denying her the right to a
  jury trial because the issues raised by the amended pleadings were triable by
  jury, she timely moved to transfer the case to the jury docket, and she
  inadvertently failed to demand a jury trial initially; and (2) refusing to rule
  on her motion to reconsider the order denying a jury trial until after the
  bench trial was concluded.
1.Â  We agree with Holmes that the circuit court properly
  denied Pyeâ€™s motion on the basis it was untimely.Â  Pye filed this complaint in
  September 2003 without requesting a jury trial and amended her complaint in
  October 2003, again without requesting a jury trial.Â  In her initial answer
  filed in January 2004, Holmes asserted multiple defenses, including failure to
  state a claim for which relief could be granted, judicial immunity, sovereign
  immunity under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, comparative negligence, and expiration
  of the statute of limitations.Â  Holmes also did not request a jury trial in her
  pleadings.Â  Holmes later moved to amend her answer, and the request was
  granted.Â  In her amended answer, Holmes asserted additional defenses, such as
  sole negligence, res judicata, and collateral estoppel.Â  The amended answer
  also admitted some of the allegations that had been denied in the original
  answer.Â  It was not until May 5, 2006, that Pye formally moved for the case to
  be transferred to the jury roster. 
Rule
  38 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure governs requests for a jury
  trial as of right and provides a party must serve a demand upon the other party
  in writing not later than ten days after the last pleading addressed to the
  issue or else a jury trial is waived:

	(b)
  Demand. Â Any party may demand a
  trial by jury of any issue triable of right by a jury by serving upon the other
  parties a demand therefor in writing at any time after the commencement of the
  action and not later than 10 days after the service of the last pleading
  directed to such issue. Such demand may be endorsed upon a pleading of the
  party.
	. . . . 
	(d)
      Waiver. Â The failure of a party to serve a demand as
  required by this rule and to file it as required by Rule 5(d) constitutes a
  waiver by him of trial by jury. A demand for trial by jury made as herein
  provided may not be withdrawn without the consent of the parties, except where
  an opposing party is in default under Rule 55(a).


  Rule 38, SCRCP.
Rule 39(b), SCRCP further
  provides:Â  â€œIssues of law and
  issues not demanded for trial by jury as provided in Rule 38 shall be tried by
  the court or may be referred to a master as provided in Rule 53; but,
  notwithstanding the failure of a party to demand a jury in an action in which
  such a demand might have been made of right, the court in its discretion upon motion may order a trial by jury of any or all issues.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]
Rule 38(b), SCRCP
  requires a motion to transfer a matter to the jury roster be made not later
  than ten days after the last pleading addressed to the issue.Â  In this case, we
  first note the motion to transfer was made more than ten days after the last
  amended answer and thus did not comply with Rule 38.Â  In addition, Pye admitted
  at the hearing on the motion that she did not comply with the requirements of
  Rule 38.
In King
  v. Shorter, 291 S.C. 501, 354 S.E.2d 402 (Ct. App. 1987), this court held
  that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in granting a motion to amend
  an answer to assert a counterclaim for unfair trade practices while denying a
  motion to transfer the case to the jury roster.Â  We noted three previous sets
  of pleadings had been filed without a request for a jury trial being made.Â  Id. at 502, 354 S.E.2d at 403.Â  In King, we stated:Â  â€œ[A] litigantâ€™s
  entitlement to a jury trial on the issues presented by an amended pleading,
  when no prior demand for a jury trial has been made, turns on whether the
  amended pleadings create new issues of fact.â€Â  Id. at 503, 354 S.E.2d at
  403.Â  We concluded that the pleadings involved essentially the same facts and
  thus the trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying the motion to the
  jury calendar.Â  Id. 
Similarly,
  the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in this instance as Pye did not
  formally request a jury trial until the action had been pending for almost
  three years, Pyeâ€™s motion was made, in any event, more than ten days after the
  last pleading addressed to the issue, and the amended pleading involved
  essentially the same facts.Â  Further, Pye expressly conceded that she failed to
  comply with the requirements of Rule 38.Â  In denying the motion, the circuit
  court expressed concern about the delay of the case, the reason for Pyeâ€™s failure
  to request a jury trial, and the prejudice to Holmes in having to prepare for a
  jury trial.Â  Thus, we cannot say the circuit court abused its discretion in
  this instance. 
2.Â  As to Pyeâ€™s allegation that the circuit court erred in
  failing to rule on her motion to reconsider until the bench trial was held, an
  order denying a mode of trial is immediately appealable if it denies a mode of
  trial to which the party is entitled.Â  In Satcher v. Satcher, 351 S.C.
  477, 570 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 2002), we held that an order under Rule 38
  affecting the mode of trial affects substantial rights and must be immediately
  appealed or any alleged error is waived.Â  We concluded the appellantâ€™s appeal
  of the denial of his motion for a jury trial under Rule 38 was untimely and therefore
  could not be considered on appeal because he did not appeal until after the
  trial had already been held.Â  Id. at 490, 570 S.E.2d at 542.Â  However,
  we did consider the appellantâ€™s argument under Rule 39(b) as to whether the
  trial court had erred in failing to grant the motion as a matter of
  discretion.Â  We stated, â€œA decision denying a jury trial based on Rule 39(b) is
  discretionary and not immediately appealable.â€Â  Id. Â We held the
  appellant had shown no abuse of discretion, however, because the trial court
  had denied the request after considering the issues involved, the prejudice to
  the appellant, the timeliness of the request, the docket, and the reason for
  the delay.Â  In addition to the trial courtâ€™s reasons, our court stated we were
  unable to discern any prejudice to the appellant because the legal
  counterclaims had been dismissed in the action.Â  Id.Â  
In
  the case before us, Pye was not entitled to a jury trial as a matter of right
  based on the filing of the amended answer as it was based on essentially the
  same factual allegations.Â  Pye clearly failed to timely demand a jury trial and
  the amended answer did not resurrect this right that had been waived.Â  A mode
  of trial ruling is immediately appealable only if denies a mode of trial to
  which the party is entitled as a matter of right.Â  The matter of a jury trial
  here was an issue committed to the discretion of the circuit court once it was
  waived, and we have found no abuse of discretion in this instance.Â  Because the
  decision on the request for a jury trial was a matter committed to the
  discretion of the court, it was not immediately appealable and Pye has shown no
  error in the timing of the courtâ€™s ruling.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.




[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        Historic Charleston Foundation and Preservation Society of Charleston, Appellants,

Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-252
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 7, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled August
1, 2008

APPEAL AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Edward K. Pritchard, III, G. Trenholm Walker and Lindsay K.

        David B. McCormack, Frances I. Cantwell, William B. Regan and

PER CURIAM: Â The
  Historic Charleston Foundation and Preservation Society of Charleston appeal
  the trial courtâ€™s order affirming the City of Charleston Board of Zoning
  Appealsâ€™ renewal of a special exception to allow the building of a hotel.Â  We
  affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Gordon v.
    Phillips Utils., Inc., 362 S.C. 403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe
  primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€); Knotts
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res., 348 S.C. 1, 10, 558 S.E.2d 511, 516 (2002)
  (â€œWhat a legislature says in the text of a statute is considered the best
  evidence of the legislative intent or will.â€); City of Myrtle Beach v. Juel
    P. Corp., 344 S.C. 43, 47, 543 S.E.2d 538, 540 (2001) (stating that when
  interpreting an ordinance, legislative intent must prevail if it can be
  reasonably discovered in the language used, and that we must give words their plain
  and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to
  limit or expand the ordinanceâ€™s operation); Historic Charleston Found. v.
    Krawcheck, 313 S.C. 500, 505, 443 S.E.2d 401, 405 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating
  the courts give deference to the interpretation of a zoning ordinance by the
  board that is charged with its interpretation); Capco of Summerville, Inc.
    v. J.H. Gayle Constr. Co., 368 S.C. 137, 142, 628 S.E.2d 38, 41 (2006) (â€œWhere
  there is one statute addressing an issue in general terms and another statute
  dealing with the identical issue in a more specific and definite manner, the
  more specific statute will be considered an exception to, or a qualifier of,
  the general statute and given such effect.â€); Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of Physical
    Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452, 485, 636 S.E.2d 598, 615 (2006) (stating due
  process is flexible and calls for such procedural protections as the particular
  situation demands and that the requirements in a particular case depend on the
  importance of the interest involved and the circumstances under which the
  deprivation may occur.).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Denise G.
      Taylor, Appellant,
				v.
				Thomas D. Taylor, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â Roger E. Henderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-255
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 14, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Elizabeth Rogers Munnerlyn, of Bennettsville, and John S. Nichols,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Thomas D. Taylor, of Summerville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  action involves collection of a child support arrearage totaling $84,167.71.Â  Denise
  G. Taylor (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order requiring Thomas D. Taylor
  (Father) to repay the arrearage at a rate of $200.00 per month, declining to
  garnish Fatherâ€™s Social Security Disability benefits to pay the arrearage, and
  declining to order Fatherâ€™s arrearage reported to credit reporting agencies.Â 
  We Â­Â­Â­Â­Â­affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]Â  
FACTS
Father and Mother divorced in 1997.Â  Mother received custody of
  their two minor daughters, and the family court ordered Father to pay monthly child
  support directly to Mother.[2]Â 
  Father quickly fell behind in his child support payments.Â  In 1998 and 2004, Mother
  initiated contempt proceedings in the family court to force Father to pay the arrearage.Â  
In 1998, the family court found Fatherâ€™s arrearage was $7,968.00, held
  Father in contempt, and sentenced him to thirty days in the county jail unless
  he adhered to the new payment schedule.Â  The family court changed the payment
  schedule from monthly to weekly, required Father to pay support through the
  Clerk of Court rather than directly to Mother, and garnished Fatherâ€™s wages.Â  
On February 1, 2002, Father sustained a work-related injury.Â 
  Father settled his Workerâ€™s Compensation claim for $82,500.00.Â  Father also
  filed a claim for Social Security Disability benefits listing both children as
  dependents.Â  
In November 2004, the family court found Fatherâ€™s arrearage was
  $82,818.80, held father in contempt, and sentenced him to six months in the
  county jail unless he made payments totaling $41,409.40 to Mother and $750.00
  to Motherâ€™s attorneys by December 15, 2004.Â  The family court reprimanded both
  Father and Mother for failing to route Fatherâ€™s intermittent support payments
  through the Clerk of Court.Â  Furthermore, the family court found the parties
  had agreed not to require Father to pay child support from November 2002
  through 2003, because their older daughter, Holly, had lived with Father during
  that period.Â  The South Carolina Department of Social Services and Department
  of Juvenile Justice took custody of Holly in January 2004.Â  Both parties were
  ordered to pay support for Holly to the Department of Social Services.Â  Mother
  retained custody of the younger child.Â  Because Fatherâ€™s Social Security
  Disability claim was still pending, the family court held the issue of Fatherâ€™s
  child support obligation in abeyance until after resolution of his Social
  Security Disability claim. 
Father failed to make the required payments and served the jail
  sentence.Â  In July 2005, the family court continued the hearing on Motherâ€™s
  rule to show cause because Mother was unable to obtain service on Father.Â  In
  November 2005, the family court again continued the hearing in an effort to
  allow both parties to present additional evidence concerning the amount of the
  arrearage. Â 
In January 2006, the family court held a final hearing on Fatherâ€™s
  arrearage.Â  Mother presented her records of Fatherâ€™s payments and of payments
  she had received for the children from the Social Security Administration.Â  Father
  asserted he had made payments in addition to those reflected in Motherâ€™s
  records and had exchanged child support payments for items like tires and
  furniture.Â  However, he failed to present any evidence supporting these
  assertions.Â  Consequently, the family court found Father had made payments
  totaling $28,292.60 since the entry of the initial order of support in 1997.Â  The
  family court also found Father had expended $30,000.00 of his Workerâ€™s
  Compensation settlement to make a down payment on a home titled solely in his sisterâ€™s
  name.Â  Additionally, Father had received a lump-sum payment of $23,516.20 and
  had begun receiving monthly Social Security Disability benefits of $1,291.20
  through December 2005 and $1,343.50 beginning in January 2006.Â  The family
  court awarded Mother interest on the arrears through February 1, 2002, the date
  Father became disabled, and terminated child support as of February 1, 2002,
  because of Fatherâ€™s disability.Â  The family court recalculated Fatherâ€™s
  arrearage as $84,167.71 and required Father to repay this amount in monthly
  increments of $200.00. Â 
Mother filed a motion to reconsider seeking rulings on her request
  for garnishment of Fatherâ€™s Social Security Disability benefits, her request
  for an order requiring Fatherâ€™s arrearage to be reported to credit bureaus, and
  other issues.Â  In August 2006, the family court found Father had failed to pay
  anything under the new schedule.Â  The family court held Father in contempt
  again and sentenced him to ninety days in the county jail unless he paid Mother
  $1,200.00 by the end of the next day.Â  The family court denied Motherâ€™s motion
  for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.[3]Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  question of child support is largely within the discretion of the family court,
  whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 305, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  An
  abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or
  where the order, based upon the findings of fact, is without evidentiary
  support. Â Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct.
  App. 1996). Â An appellate court will reverse a manifest abuse of discretion
  where the error of law is â€œso opposed to the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion as
  to amount to a deprivation of the legal rights of the party.â€Â  Jeter v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  369 S.C. 433, 438, 633 S.E.2d 143, 145-46 (2006).Â  The term â€œabuse of
  discretionâ€ does not reflect negatively on the trial court; rather, it merely
  indicates the appellate court believes an error of law occurred in the
  circumstances at hand.Â  Macauley v. Query, 193 S.C. 1, 5, 7 S.E.2d 519,
  521 (1940).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Repayment
  ScheduleÂ  
Mother
  asserts the family court erred in ordering Father to repay the $84,167.71
  arrearage in increments of $200.00 per month, because repayment at this rate
  would span approximately thirty-five years.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œThe
  family court has exclusive jurisdiction . . . to determine the manner in which
  sums ordered paid for support shall be paid and applied.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-420(A)(21) (Supp. 2007).Â  However, â€œ[e]quity will always endeavor to
  provide a remedy where one has a right violated.â€Â  Matheson v. McCormac,
  186 S.C. 93, 100, 195 S.E. 122, 125 (1938).
The
  family court erred in requiring Father to repay a child support obligation
  totaling more than $84,000.00 at a rate of only $200.00 per month when he
  possessed the means to pay more.Â  Father began receiving $1,343.50 per month in
  Social Security Disability benefits beginning in January 2006.Â  No evidence
  exists that this income supported anyone other than himself.Â  Father stated it was
  his only income.[4]Â 
  The $200.00 payment ordered by the family court, and ignored by Father, was a
  mere fifteen percent of this monthly benefit.Â  Moreover, as Mother argues, even
  faithful repayment at this rate would take more than thirty-five years.Â  The
  children supported by this order would be more than fifty years old before
  repayment was complete.Â  Where Father has the means to pay more, we view this
  rate as an abuse of discretion.Â  
Fatherâ€™s
  monthly payment toward the arrearage should increase to an amount that will
  enable him to repay his child support obligation as quickly as possible while
  still providing for his own needs.Â  Mother argues in favor of an order
  requiring Father to pay sixty-five percent of his Social Security Disability
  benefit, or approximately $873.00 per month, toward this debt.Â  While this rate
  would shrink the term of Fatherâ€™s repayment to approximately eight years, it
  would leave Father unable to provide for his own needs. Â Father testified that
  although he paid $30,000 toward the purchase of the home he occupied, he paid
  rent of $984.00 per month on that home rather than a mortgage.Â  Father
  testified to approximately $200.00 in monthly living expenses, not including
  rent, food, transportation, or insurance.Â  However, we are unable to determine
  the total amount of Fatherâ€™s current monthly living expenses.Â  Therefore, we
  look to the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (Guidelines) for assistance
  in determining a fair and adequate amount to set aside to meet Fatherâ€™s needs.[5]Â 
  The Guidelines recognize a self support reserve of $748.00 per month to ensure
  the obligor â€œhas sufficient income available to maintain a minimum standard of
  livingâ€ and provide for himself.Â  S.C. Code Regs. Â§ 114-4720(A)(11) (Supp.
  2007).Â  Setting aside this amount as the minimum necessary to meet Fatherâ€™s own
  needs, Father realizes a monthly surplus of $595.50.Â  We believe Father should be
  able to repay his support obligation at a rate of $350.00 per month. 
II.  Garnishment
Mother
  asserts the family court erred in declining to order garnishment of Fatherâ€™s
  Social Security Disability benefits.Â  We agree.
The
  income of a child support obligor â€œis subject to immediate withholding as of
  the effective date of the order without the requirement that an arrearage
  accumulateâ€ unless the parties agree or a court finds good cause not to order
  the income withheld.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1315(B)(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  The
  amount of income withheld must comply with limits enunciated in the Federal
  Consumer Credit Protection Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1315(F)(2)(b) (Supp.
  2007).Â  Under the Federal Consumer Credit Protection Act, where an obligor is
  not supporting either a spouse or a dependent child who is not the subject of
  the support order, and where the support has been owed for more than twelve
  weeks, the maximum weekly income subject to withholding for payment of a
  support order is sixty-five percent.Â  15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1673(b)(2) (West 1998).Â  Moneys
  payable by the United States government to an individual as â€œremuneration for
  employmentâ€ are subject to withholding to satisfy support orders.Â  42 U.S.C.A. Â§
  659(a) (West Supp. 2007).Â  Moneys subject to withholding include those â€œamounts
  payable on account of personal services performed by the individual or any
  other individual,â€ such as Social Security Disability benefits.Â  42 U.S.C.A. Â§
  659(h)(1)(A) (West Supp. 2007).Â  
The
  family court erred in failing to order garnishment of Fatherâ€™s Social Security
  Disability benefits.Â  Clearly, under South Carolina and federal law, Fatherâ€™s Social
  Security Disability income is subject to withholding to satisfy his child
  support obligation.Â  Section 20-7-1315(B)(1) creates a presumption in favor of garnishment,
  with the obligor bearing the resultant burden of proving why the family court
  should refrain from withholding his income.Â  In the matter at hand, we find
  Father has failed to show good cause for the family court not to order his support
  payments withheld from income.Â  On the contrary, Fatherâ€™s record of non-payment
  militates strongly in favor of garnishment.Â  Father disposed of his Workerâ€™s
  Compensation and Social Security Disability lump-sum payments totaling more
  than $100,000 without diverting any of those funds to satisfy his child support
  obligation.Â  Furthermore, Father failed to make a single payment under the
  family courtâ€™s final order.Â  The family court sentenced Father to jail on three
  separate occasions for his repeated failure to honor his support obligation.Â  In
  light of Fatherâ€™s refusal to honor the family courtâ€™s previous orders, we see
  no likelihood he will voluntarily comply in the future.Â  In the absence of a
  written agreement or a showing to the contrary, the family court abused its
  discretion in failing to order garnishment of Fatherâ€™s Social Security
  Disability benefits.Â  
III.  Credit Reporting
  Agencies
Mother
  asserts the family court erred in declining to order that Fatherâ€™s arrearage be
  reported to credit reporting agencies.Â  We disagree.Â  
Federal
  law requires each State to enact laws establishing procedures for periodically
  reporting to â€œconsumer reporting agenciesâ€ the names of noncustodial parents
  delinquent in paying child support, as well as the amounts unpaid.Â  42 U.S.C.A.
  Â§ 666(a)(7) (Supp. 2007).Â  In South Carolina, the Department of Social Services
  â€œprovide[s] consumer credit reporting agencies an automated monthly report of
  obligors in Title IV-D cases who have an arrearage in an amount of one thousand
  dollars or greater.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-5-585(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  
Mother
  relies on federal law to support her assertion that the family court erred in
  declining to order Fatherâ€™s arrearage reported to credit reporting agencies.Â 
  Motherâ€™s reliance on that law is misplaced.Â  The federal statute required States
  to enact laws establishing certain administrative procedures to ease interstate
  collection of child support arrearages as a condition to the Statesâ€™ receiving
  federal moneys for children and families.Â  The South Carolina Legislature
  complied with this mandate by enacting section 43-5-585(A), under which the
  South Carolina Department of Social Services reports arrearages in certain
  interstate child support cases to credit reporting agencies monthly.Â  The
  family court does not enact laws on behalf of the State and therefore is not
  bound to fashion its orders in compliance with this statute.Â  S.C. Const. Art.
  I, Â§ 8.Â  Consequently, the family court did not err in declining to order
  Fatherâ€™s arrearage reported.Â  
CONCLUSION
As to the issue of
  the rate at which Father shall repay his child support arrearage, we find the
  family court erred in setting Fatherâ€™s rate of repayment at $200.00 per month.Â 
  We find Father is capable of paying $350.00 per month.Â  Accordingly, we modify
  the order of the family court to require Father to repay his child support
  arrearage at a rate of $350.00 per month.Â  
As to the issue of
  garnishment of Fatherâ€™s monthly Social Security Disability benefits, we find
  the family court erred in declining to issue an order to withhold Fatherâ€™s
  income.Â  Father has demonstrated a blatant disregard for the orders of the
  family court and will not likely repay his obligation voluntarily.Â 
  Consequently, we reverse the order of the family court on this issue and remand
  to the family court with instructions to issue an order requiring withholding
  of the amount of Fatherâ€™s monthly payment toward his child support arrearage.
As to the issue of
  reporting Fatherâ€™s arrearage to credit reporting services, we find the family
  court did not err.Â  South Carolina law requires that child support arrearages
  collected through the South Carolina Department of Social Services be reported
  to credit reporting services on a monthly basis.Â  However, no such law compels
  the family court to report arrearages.Â  Therefore, we affirm the order of the
  family court on this issue.Â  
Accordingly, the
  order of the family court in this matter is 
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
SHORT and KONDUROS,
  JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The family court ordered Father to pay $2,500.00 per
  month for the first five months, then $1,110.00 per month thereafter.Â  
[3] Father did not file a respondentâ€™s brief in this
  matter.Â  â€œUpon the failure of respondent to timely file a brief, the appellate
  court may take such action as it deems proper.â€Â  Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR.Â  
[4] We acknowledge Motherâ€™s argument that federal law
  would permit Father to earn additional income up to $900.00 per month without
  reducing his Social Security Disability benefit.Â  However, no evidence
  indicates Father has been able to work for more than a few weeks since he
  became disabled.Â  We therefore decline to impute employment income to him for
  purposes of determining an appropriate rate of repayment.Â  
[5] The family court discontinued Fatherâ€™s support order
  due to his disability, and the child support arrearage is no longer
  accumulating.Â  Ongoing child support is no longer an issue in this matter, and
  therefore, the Guidelines are not mandatory in this matter.Â  However, we
  believe the Guidelinesâ€™ self support reserve, calculated to protect obligor
  parents, aids us in establishing a baseline income amount to provide for
  Fatherâ€™s own needs.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

				Ted Dean
      Hatcher, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-256
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 14, 2008
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia;
  and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Ted
  Dean Hatcher appeals his conviction for assault and battery with intent to kill
  (ABWIK), alleging the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the
  lesser included offense of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature
  (ABHAN).Â  We reverse and remand.[1]Â  
FACTS
Hatcher was charged with ABWIK against
  Cedrick Lyles after Hatcher shot Lyles while Lyles was stopped in his car in
  front of Hatcherâ€™s trailer.Â  Hatcher claimed he thought he saw Lyles reaching
  for a weapon and shot off his gun in self defense.Â  
At
  trial, Hatcher testified that he bought crack cocaine from Lyles the night
  before the shooting.Â  When Hatcher returned home that night, roughly thirty
  minutes later, he saw a car parked outside his trailer with its inside lights
  on.Â  As he drove closer, he saw Lyles run from the back of the car and jump in
  his driverâ€™s side door.Â  Hatcherâ€™s girlfriend, Ferrin Brown, was standing at the
  back of the car crying.Â  Lyles asked Hatcher to get in the car and talk.Â  He
  told Hatcher that Brown loved Hatcher and would never â€œdo nothing behind
  [Hatcherâ€™s] back.â€Â  Lyles said he knew the two had been arguing and wanted to
  help them work through their problems.Â  Hatcher got out of the car and Lyles
  followed him into the trailer.Â  
Inside,
  Brown was sitting in the bathroom crying.Â  Lyles said he was going to help them
  â€œtalk through this,â€ but Hatcher told him he did not need help and asked Lyles to
  leave.Â  After Lyles left, Hatcher went back to Brown, slapped her, and asked
  her what was going on.Â  Eventually, Brown told him that she had been raped but
  refused to go to the hospital.Â  
Hatcher
  testified that he called Lyles several times the next day and told him he knew
  what had happened the night before and he was going to â€œwhoop his ass.â€Â  Lyles
  said he would come by Hatcherâ€™s house and â€œtake care of you both.â€Â  Hatcher
  testified he thought Lyles was going to shoot him and Brown, so he borrowed a
  gun from a friend for protection.Â  He also said he knew Lyles carried a gun and
  had seen him with a weapon two weeks earlier.Â  
Hatcher
  testified when Lyles arrived later that day, Lyles stopped his car and said
  â€œwhatâ€™s up.â€ Â Hatcher then saw him â€œlean forward in his driverâ€™s seat and reach
  like this.â€Â  Hatcher said he thought Lyles was reaching for a gun, so, without
  taking aim, Hatcher began to shoot.Â  After firing the gun, Lyles put his foot
  on the gas and drove straight into the woods.Â  Hatcher ran back to his trailer
  and told his father what happened.Â  Hatcher left his trailer, threw the gun in
  the lake, and went to his brotherâ€™s house where the police found him the next
  day. Â 
According to Lyles, Hatcher called and told him to come by the
  trailer. Hatcher told Lyles that he needed to talk and he had something for him.
  Â As Lyles approached Hatcherâ€™s house, he saw him about 50 yards from his
  driveway.Â  Lyles pulled over, rolled down his window, and greeted Hatcher.Â 
  Lyles testified Hatcher accused him of messing with Brown and began shooting.Â  Lyles
  was shot several times, sustaining gunshot wounds to his left upper abdomen,
  left eye, left neck, and left shoulder.Â  Lyles lost control of his car and it
  veered off the road.Â  Lyles claimed Hatcher went through his pockets and then
  ran from the scene.Â  Lyles got out of the car and managed to walk until an officer
  saw him in the street covered in blood.Â  
At trial, Hatcher requested the judge charge the jury on ABHAN as
  a lesser-included offense of ABWIK.Â  The judge stated that he would not charge
  the lesser-included offense because â€œthere wasnâ€™t any fist and there wasnâ€™t
  anything else other than a .38 shot five times.â€Â  He concluded, â€œeither he
  acted in self-defense or intent to kill the guyâ€ and refused to charge ABHAN.Â  The
  judge charged the jury with ABWIK, possession of a weapon during the commission
  of a crime, and the defense of self-defense.Â  The jury found Hatcher guilty of
  ABWIK and possession of a firearm. Â The judge sentenced Hatcher to twenty years
  for ABWIK and five years for possession of a firearm.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
If any evidence supports a jury charge,
  the trial judge should grant the request.Â  State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004)Â 
  Â The law to be charged is determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State
    v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 231, 625 S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œDue process requires that a lesser
  included offense be charged when the evidence warrants it but only if the
  evidence would permit a jury rationally to find the defendant guilty of the
  lesser offense.â€Â  State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92, 94, 413 S.E.2d 870, 871
  (Ct. App. 1992).Â Â Â  
In
  criminal cases, this court sits to review only errors of law.Â  State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Â â€œTo
  warrant reversal, a trial court's refusal to give a requested jury charge must
  be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.â€ Â Patterson, 367
  S.C. at 232, 625 S.E.2d at 245.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Hatcher
  argues the trial judge erred by refusing to charge the jury on ABHAN.Â  We agree.
Initially, we address the Stateâ€™s contention that Hatcher failed
  to preserve this issue for appeal because he offered a â€œbare bonesâ€ jury charge
  and did not object to the trial judgeâ€™s jury instructions.Â  We disagree.Â  
In State v. Johnson, the South Carolina Supreme Court
  clarified it is â€œthe long-standing rule that where a party requests a jury
  charge and, after opportunity for discussion, the trial judge declines the
  charge, it is unnecessary, to preserve the point on appeal, to renew the
  request at conclusion of the courtâ€™s instruction.â€Â  333 S.C. 62, 64 n.1, 508
  S.E.2d 29, 30 n.1 (1998).Â  The court reiterated the rule because it found its
  earlier decision in State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683 (1996)
  was misinterpreted.Â  Whipple was being read as indicating that where a
  partyâ€™s jury charge objections or requests are denied on the record after a
  pre-charge conference, the party must renew those objections or requests
  subsequent to the court's instructions to the jury.Â  Id.Â  In Johnson,
  the court explained because there was no on-the-record discussion regarding
  whether the judge would give Whippleâ€™s jury charge, there was no on-the-record
  ruling as to whether the court would give a certain charge.Â  Id.Â 
  Therefore, Whipple failed to preserve the issue by failing to object to the
  judgeâ€™s charge as given.Â  Id.Â  Conversely, the court found Johnsonâ€™s
  request to charge was denied on-the-record after an opportunity for
  discussion.Â  Therefore, the court found Johnson was not required to renew his
  request at the conclusion of the charge. Â Id. 
As in Johnson, Hatcher made an on-the-record request for an
  ABHAN charge.Â  The court afforded an opportunity for discussion, eliciting discussion
  from both Hatcher and the Solicitor.Â  After the discussion, the trial judge
  stated, â€œIâ€™m not going to charge the lesser included offense.â€Â  The judge
  proceeded to charge the jury on ABWIK, possession of a weapon during the commission of a crime, and the
  defense of self-defense.Â  We
  find Hatcher was not required to renew his request at the conclusion of the
  charge and therefore, this issue is preserved for our review.Â  Â Â Â 
We next address
  whether the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the lesser included offense
  of ABHAN.Â  ABWIK is an unlawful act of a violent nature to the person of
  another with malice aforethought, either express or implied.Â  State v. Foust,
  325 S.C. 12, 14, 479 S.E.2d 50, 51 (1996).Â  Malice is a required element of
  ABWIK.Â  State v. Kinard, 373 S.C. 500, 504, 646 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  With the exception of the death of the victim, each element of
  murder must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt in order for a jury to convict
  a defendant of ABWIK.Â  Kinard at 503, 646 S.E.2d at 169.Â  Malice
  aforethought, which encompasses acts committed with extreme recklessness, satisfies
  the general intent required for a conviction of ABWIK.Â  Id. at 505-06,
  646 S.E.2d at 170.
On the other hand, ABHAN is an unlawful act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances of
  aggravation.Â  State v. Fennell, 
  340 S.C. 266, 274, 531 S.E.2d 512, 516 (2000)Â  Circumstances of aggravation
  include the use of a deadly weapon, infliction of serious bodily injury, intent
  to commit a felony, great disparity between the ages and physical conditions of
  the parties involved, and a difference in the sexes. Â Id. at 274, 531
  S.E.2d at 516-17.Â  The absence of malice is not a required element of ABHAN,
  and the fact that a defendant acts with malice does not preclude a finding of
  ABHAN.Â  State v. Tyler, 348 S.C. 526, 530-31, 560 S.E.2d 888, 890
  (2002). Â 
In
  determining whether the evidence required the judge to charge the jury on
  ABHAN, this court must view the facts in the light most favorable to the
  defendant.Â  See State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 321, 474
  S.E.2d 430, 431 (1996).Â  In this case, examining the evidence in a light most
  favorable to Hatcher, a jury could conclude that he is guilty of only ABHAN.Â  Hatcher
  testified that he stood 3-4 feet away from Lyles car and did not aim when he
  shot the gun.Â  He then stated he initially did not know whether he hit Lyles
  because he did not aim the gun at Lyles, rather he just pulled the gun and
  fired it.Â  Further, Lyles sustained gunshot wounds to various parts of his
  body, indicating Hatcher may have simply been shooting in Lylesâ€™ direction in
  an attempt at self preservation whether legally justified or not.Â  While the
  jury ultimately rejected the issue of self-defense, that determination is not
  dispositive of the issue.Â  Furthermore, while the evidence in this case may
  give rise to an inference the shooting was committed with malice, the inference
  is a permissive one which the jury is free to accept or reject.Â  See State
    v. Pilgrim, 320 S.C. 409, 415 n.3, 465 S.E.2d 108, 112 n.3 (Ct. App. 1995), overruled on other grounds by State v. Foust, 325 S.C. 12, 479
  S.E.2d 50 (1996).Â  
Accordingly,
  because there is evidence to support an ABHAN instruction, we find the trial
  judge erred in failing to charge the lesser-included offense of ABHAN and that
  the appellant was prejudiced by this error. Â Furthermore,
  in reversing Hatcherâ€™s ABWIK conviction, we must also reverse the conviction
  for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime because
  the former conviction is a prerequisite to the latter.Â  E.g., S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(E) (2003) (noting the additional punishment for possession of
  a firearm during the commission of a violent crime may not be imposed unless
  the defendant is convicted of the underlying violent crime); State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 235 n.4, 589 S.E.2d 1, 5 n.4 (2003) (noting defendant's
  conviction for possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime
  must be reversed where the court was reversing defendant's murder conviction). Â Based
  on the foregoing, Hatcherâ€™s convictions are hereby
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        In the Matter
          of the Care and Treatment of Roger Dale McCoy, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-261
Heard March 6, 2008 â€“ Filed May 15, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Assistant
          Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this commitment action under the Sexually Violent Predator Act (Act)[1], Roger Dale McCoy appeals the circuit
  courtâ€™s allowance of certain testimony by the Stateâ€™s expert witness.Â  McCoy
  contends the testimony was irrelevant, was unfairly prejudicial, and improperly brought into issue the character of his
  expert witness. Â We affirm.Â  
FACTS
McCoy pled guilty to two counts of first-degree criminal sexual
  conduct and one count of indecent exposure.Â  He was incarcerated for those crimes
  in 1998.Â  In 2004, pursuant to the Act, the South Carolina Department of
  Corrections (Department) assessed McCoy and determined he was a sexually
  violent predator as defined by section 44-48-30 of the South Carolina Code.Â 
  The Department then petitioned the circuit court to order a formal evaluation
  of McCoy and, if a jury determined he was a sexually violent predator under the
  Act, to commit McCoy to the custody of the South Carolina Department of Mental
  Health for care and treatment until he could safely re-enter society.Â Â Â  
The circuit court found probable cause existed for McCoyâ€™s
  continued detention and ordered McCoy evaluated.Â  On June 21, 2005, the circuit
  court tried the issue of whether McCoy should be committed as a sexually
  violent predator.Â  During the trial, McCoy cross-examined the Stateâ€™s expert
  witness, Dr. Pamela Crawford, as to her expert opinion. McCoy then presented
  attorney Larry Crane, who testified Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony in McCoyâ€™s trial
  differed from her testimony in prior sexually violent predator trials.Â  During
  Dr. Crawfordâ€™s rebuttal testimony, McCoy questioned whether she had referred a
  serial rapist to the defense expert, Dr. Thomas Martin, and attorney Crane.Â  Dr.
  Crawfordâ€™s affirmative response included statements that Dr. Martin was â€œ[a]
  doctor who had a very liberal sense of letting people goâ€ and â€œwho lets people
  go and is known in the community for letting people go when theyâ€™re very
  dangerous.â€Â  Dr. Crawford further stated she had recommended Dr. Martin and
  Crane to the other patient because she believed they were the people most
  likely to â€œget [him] off.â€Â  McCoy objected to these statements.Â  Although the
  circuit court stopped Dr. Crawford from testifying as to the details of another
  case in which Crane represented a sexually violent predator, it permitted Dr.
  Crawford to continue her testimony regarding Dr. Martin and Crane and allowed
  McCoy to question Dr. Crawford further.Â  
The jury ultimately found McCoy was a sexually violent predator.Â 
  The circuit court ordered McCoy committed to the Department of Mental Health for
  long-term treatment upon completion of his sentence.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  admission of evidence is within the discretion of the circuit court and will
  not be reversed by an appellate court absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State
    v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).Â  A circuit
  courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony constitutes an
  abuse of discretion when the ruling is manifestly arbitrary, unreasonable, or
  unfair.Â  Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609
  S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
McCoy
  argues the circuit court erred in allowing Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony concerning Dr.
  Martin.Â  McCoy contends the testimony was irrelevant, was unfairly prejudicial,
  and improperly brought into issue Dr. Martinâ€™s character.Â  We disagree.Â  
I. Relevance
McCoyâ€™s
  objection to Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony as irrelevant is unpersuasive.Â  â€œâ€˜Relevant
  evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œA witness
  may be cross-examined on any matter relevant to any issue in the case,
  including credibility.â€Â  Rule 611, SCRE.Â  A witness may be re-examined and
  cross-examined to rebut the testimony of another witness.Â  Id.Â  Any
  party may impeach a witness.Â  Rule 607, SCRE.Â  
Under
  Rule 401, Dr. Crawfordâ€™s credentials, expert opinion, and credibility were all
  relevant to the question of whether McCoy fit the criteria of a sexually
  violent predator under the Act.Â  As an expert witness, Dr. Crawford offered
  expert testimony on which the jury could choose to rely in making its decision.Â 
  McCoyâ€™s first cross-examination of Dr. Crawford elicited her credentials and tested
  her expert opinion.Â  After examining attorney Crane regarding Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  testimony at prior trials, McCoy attempted to use his second cross-examination
  of Dr. Crawford to diminish her credibility.Â  During this second encounter,
  McCoy questioned whether Dr. Crawford had referred another patient to Dr.
  Martin and attorney Crane.Â  Dr. Crawford answered and explained why she had
  made the referral.Â  The circuit court maintained control over the interrogation
  of Dr. Crawford, stopping her answer when it no longer pertained to the
  question and exercising appropriate discretion by allowing Dr. Crawford to
  explain her answer.Â  Because Dr. Crawfordâ€™s statements were relevant, the
  circuit court did not abuse its discretion in admitting her testimony.Â  
II. Unfair Prejudice
McCoyâ€™s
  argument that even if Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony was relevant, it nevertheless was
  unfairly prejudicial, is equally unsuccessful.Â  Otherwise relevant evidence
  â€œmay be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the
  danger of unfair prejudice.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  To warrant reversal based on the
  admission or exclusion of evidence, the complaining party must prove both the
  error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice.  Fields, 363 S.C. at
  26, 609 S.E.2d at 509.Â  To show prejudice, reasonable probability must exist
  that the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack
  thereof.  Id.Â  
On
  appeal, McCoy fails to prove prejudice.Â  McCoy asserts Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony
  implied Dr. Martinâ€™s â€œprofessional opinion was for saleâ€ and the State
  â€œexploitedâ€ this testimony in closing argument.Â  However, the trial transcript
  supports neither assertion.Â  Dr. Crawfordâ€™s assessment of Dr. Martin as a
  doctor with a â€œvery liberal sense of letting people goâ€ recognized the doctorsâ€™
  opinions differed vastly without impugning Dr. Martinâ€™s integrity as an honest
  practitioner.Â  In closing argument, both parties attempted to â€œspinâ€ Dr.
  Crawfordâ€™s statements in a light favorable to their respective positions.Â 
  McCoy ridiculed Dr. Crawfordâ€™s reasoning for her referral as â€œpreposterous.â€Â 
  The State characterized it as honesty and â€œgood faith.â€Â  Neither party
  insinuated this testimony condemned Dr. Martin.Â  The trial transcript simply
  does not support an inference of reasonable probability that the disputed
  testimony influenced the jury.Â  Therefore, the circuit court did not err in
  admitting Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony.
III.Â  Hearsay
During
  cross-examination of Dr. Crawford, McCoy objected to her testimony, stating,
  â€œAnd itâ€™s hearsay about Dr. Martinâ€™s reputation in the community.â€Â  This argument
  is also meritless.Â  With limited exceptions, â€œ[e]vidence of a personâ€™s
  character or a trait of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving
  action in conformity therewith on a particular occasion.â€Â  Rule 404(a), SCRE. Â McCoy
  seems to argue on appeal Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony was offered as evidence â€œthat
  the defense expert may have been mistaken in an unrelated case.â€Â  However,
  McCoy, and not the State, elicited this testimony from Dr. Crawford.Â  Neither
  the State nor Dr. Crawford offered this testimony â€œfor the purpose of proving
  action in conformityâ€ with a trait of Dr. Martinâ€™s character, but rather for
  the purpose of explaining the bases of Dr. Crawfordâ€™s decision to make a
  referral brought into issue by McCoy himself.Â  Consequently, Rule 404(a) does

CONCLUSION
The
  circuit court did not err in admitting Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony concerning her
  decision to refer another patient to Dr. Martin.Â  With her credibility under
  attack, Dr. Crawford explained the bases for her decision to make the referral,
  and no prejudice resulted.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J.,
  PIEPER, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Melissa Burrell
      Cline, Appellant,
				v.
				Thomas A.
      Cline, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Leslie K. Riddle, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-267
Heard April 9, 2008 â€“ Filed May 16, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				O.W. Bannister, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				David Michael Collins, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, Melissa Burrell Cline (Wife) appeals the findings of the
  family court arguing: (1) the court erred in holding repayment of marital debt
  did not include interest; (2) the court erred in finding 1.1 acres of
  nonmarital property had been transmuted into marital property; and (3) the
  court abused its discretion in denying Wife alimony.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Wife and Thomas A. Cline (Husband) began
  dating when Wife was in the eighth grade.Â  After graduating high school, Wife
  and Husband married on April 24, 1993.Â  Wife and Husband have two children who
  were respectively nine years old and four years old at the time of the final hearing. 
In anticipation of marriage, Wife and Husband purchased a mobile
  home which they placed on land given to Wife by her grandfather. Â Â Husband
  assisted the grandfather in selecting, clearing, and preparing the land in
  order to place the mobile home.Â  The couple named the road used to access the
  land â€œT&M Cline Drive,â€ otherwise known as â€œTommy and Melissa Cline Drive.â€Â 
  Additionally, the land was used as collateral to secure the loan for the mobile
  home.Â  During the course of their marriage, Wife and Husband fully paid for the
  mobile home and continued to make improvements to the land.Â  
Due to
  poor financial history, Husband and Wife were unable to obtain loans from a
  bank. As a result, they borrowed money from Linda Bradley, Wifeâ€™s mother,
  throughout the marriage.Â  Although no signed documents indicate any loans or a
  promise to repay the debt, neither Husband nor Wife dispute receiving loans
  from Bradley.[1]Â 
  Instead, the parties dispute the amount owed.Â  According to Wife, each time a
  loan was received from Bradley, Bradley would establish a payment schedule with
  interest.Â  However, Husband was unaware of any payment schedule or the accrual
  of interest because Wife, using marital funds, handled the payments.Â  
Prior
  to having children, Wife worked full-time making ten dollars an hour. Â Following
  the birth of their first child, Wife continued to work on a part-time basis. Â After
  the birth of their second child, Wife left work to care for her children.Â  At
  some point during the marriage, Wife attended technical college for one and
  one-half years, but at the final hearing she claimed going back to school was
  not an option.Â  According to Husband, Wife refused to work outside of the
  home.Â  At the time of the hearing, in addition to watching her own children,
  Wife provided day care services for four additional children at the rate of
  $20.00 to $25.00 per day.Â  Husband, who at the time of the hearing was on
  short-term disability, has been employed by BMW since 1999 and makes a base pay
  of $25.15 per hour.Â  
During the course of their marriage, Husband and Wife separated on
  three occasions as a result of Husbandâ€™s extramarital affair with another
  woman.Â  The final separation occurred on February 2, 2005.Â  On May 24, 2005,
  Wife filed for divorce on the grounds of adultery and on September 19, 2006,
  the family court issued its final order and decree of divorce awarding full
  custody of the children to Wife.Â  For the purpose of determining child support,
  the family court imputed the sum of $8.00 per hour to Wife, which equates to a
  gross monthly income of $1,386.00.Â  Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income was
  calculated at $3,266.00, which was reflective of his disability pay.Â  Husband
  was ordered to pay child support of $1,121.00 per month.Â  Wife was awarded full
  ownership and possession of the marital home but did not receive an alimony
  award.Â  The family court found the land on which the marital home sits had been
  transmuted into marital property.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn
  appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find
  the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).
  However, this broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to
  disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C.
  532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Neither is the appellate court
  required to ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the
  witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and to assign
  comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375,
  380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004).Â  â€œQuestions concerning alimony rest with
  the sound discretion of the [family] court, whose conclusions will not be
  disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€  Kelley v. Kelley,
  324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).  The family court â€œabuses its discretion when factual
  findings are without evidentiary support or a ruling is based upon an error of
  law.â€  Smith v. Doe, 366 S.C. 469, 474, 623 S.E.2d 370, 372 (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Marital Debt
Wife argues the
  family court erred in its calculation of marital debt because Husband and Wife
  were expected to repay the principal owed to Bradley with interest.Â  We
  disagree.
Debts
  incurred for marital purposes are subject to equitable distribution.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œSection 20-7-472 creates a rebuttable
  presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred prior to marital litigation
  is a marital debt and must be factored into the totality of equitable
  apportionment.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 103, 545 S.E.2d 531,
  539 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Additionally,
  loans from close family members must be carefully scrutinized for legitimacy.Â  Id. at 104, 545 S.E.2d at 539.Â  
Our
  review of the record suggests that Bradley gave Husband and Wife approximately
  $41,000 with the expectation that she would be repaid.Â  Husband, Wife, and
  Bradley testified that Bradley made loans to the parties throughout the
  marriage.Â  Husband and Wife presented testimony that between $20,000 and $31,000
  had been paid back to Bradley.Â  Both Bradley and Wife stated the loans were
  interest bearing.Â  However, neither Wife nor Bradley introduced into evidence a
  promissory note or any other document as proof the payment was an interest
  bearing loan. Â Instead, the record reveals the only document indicating a
  payment schedule, including a 7.5% interest rate, was created right before the
  scheduled trial.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion in
  excluding interest when calculating the remaining balance of the marital debt
  only for the purposes of equitable distribution.[2]
II.Â  Transmutation
      
Wife asserts the
  family court erred in finding the 1.1 acres of land, a premarital gift, was
  transmuted into marital property.Â  We disagree.
Property
  acquired by either party before the marriage is nonmarital property. S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2006).
  Â While not ordinarily subject to division, a gift of real estate to one spouse
  may lose its nonmarital character if used in support of the marriage or
  otherwise utilized in such a manner as to evidence intent by the parties to
  make it marital property. Trimnal v. Trimnal, 287 S.C. 495, 497-98, 339
  S.E.2d 869, 870 (1986).Â  Property that is nonmarital at the time of its
  acquisition may be transmuted if it: (1) becomes so commingled with marital
  property as to be untraceable; (2) is titled jointly; or (3) is utilized by the
  parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an
  intent by the parties to make it marital property.Â  Id. 
â€œAs a general rule,
  transmutation is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€ Â Johnson
    v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 295, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œThe
  spouse claiming transmutation must produce objective evidence showing that, during the marriage, the parties themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.Â  Id. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 110-11.Â  If
  one spouse carries this burden, that spouse establishes a prima facie case the
  property is marital property.Â  Id. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 110.Â  If the
  opposing spouse then wishes to claim that the property so identified is not
  part of the marital estate, the opposing spouse has the burden of presenting
  evidence to establish its nonmarital character.Â  Id. 
Evidence
  that nonmarital property has been transmuted may include â€œplacing the property
  in joint names, transferring the property to the other spouse as a gift, using
  the property exclusively for marital purposes, commingling the property with
  marital property, using marital funds to build equity in the property, or
  exchanging the property for marital property.â€Â  Id. at 295, 372 S.E.2d at 111.Â  However, the
  mere use of separate property to support the marriage,
  without some additional evidence of intent to treat it as property of the
  marriage, is not sufficient to establish transmutation.Â  Id. at 295-96, 372 S.E.2d at 111.Â  
South Carolina
  courts have found sufficient evidence to establish transmutation where separate
  property is used to support the marital home.Â  Recently our court held land
  acquired by husband by gift lost its nonmarital character when husband and wife
  erected the marital home on the land.Â  Simpson v. Simpson, Op. No. 4341
  (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 8, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 7 at 71) (citing Cooper
    v. Cooper, 289 S.C. 377, 380, 346 S.E.2d 326, 328 (Ct. App. 1986)).Â  In Simpson,
  husband acquired land by gift during the marriage.Â  Thereafter, husband and
  wife cleared the land and used marital funds to build a home, which the parties
  then occupied from the time it was built in 1995 until the commencement of
  their divorce proceeding in 2004. Â Id.Â  Based on these occurrences, this
  court found the parties used the home and land in support of the marriage and
  upheld the family courtâ€™s ruling that the home was transmuted into marital
  property.Â  Id. Â Similarly, in Cooper, this court held husbandâ€™s
  nonmarital property was effectively transmuted into marital property when the
  marital home was erected thereon.Â  Cooper, 289 S.C. at 380, 346 S.E.2d
  at 328.Â  In finding Husbandâ€™s nonmarital property transmuted into marital
  property, the Cooper court reasoned: 

	[a]lthough
  the evidence shows that the husband acquired the land by gift from his father
  during the marriage, it also shows, and we so find, that the property lost its
  nonmarital character and therefore became subject to equitable distribution
  when the husband, nine years before the parties separated, erected the marital
  home thereon and thereby used the 1.4 acre tract in support of the marriage.Â 
	

Id. Â Â Here, as in Simpson and Cooper, the land given to Wife by gift effectively lost its
  nonmarital character when it was used to support the marriage.Â  Applying this
  courtâ€™s analysis in Simpson and Cooper, the use of Wifeâ€™s nonmarital
  land as the foundation to sustain the marital mobile home for the duration of
  Husband and Wifeâ€™s marriage supports the family courtâ€™s finding of transmutation.Â  
Moreover,
  the facts further evidence the intent of the parties to treat the property as
  marital property. Husband assisted in selecting, clearing, and preparing the
  land for the mobile home and the land was used as collateral to secure the loan
  to enable the purchase of the marital mobile home.Â  Husband and Wife, using
  marital funds, improved the property by installation of a sewer and septic
  tank, addition of electricity and water, and pavement of the driveway.[3]Â 
  The couple even named the road
  used to access the land under the coupleâ€™s married name, calling it â€œT&M Cline Drive.â€ Â These actions, in combination,
  evidence intent by the parties to make the land marital property.Â  As a result,
  the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding the land was
  transmuted into marital property.

    III.Â  Alimony
Wife contends the
  family court abused its discretion in denying her request for alimony.Â 
  Specifically, Wife asserts the family courtâ€™s denial of alimony was erroneously
  based on the premise that child support is a substitute for alimony and the
  courtâ€™s decision was incorrect due to error as to the other grounds of this
  appeal.Â  We disagree. 
An
  award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and will
  not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Allen v. Allen,
  347 S.C. 177, 184-85, 554 S.E.2d 421,
  424-25 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the findings
  of the family court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an
  error of law.Â  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495
  (Ct. App. 2001).
â€œAlimony
  is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital
  relationship.â€ Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113
  (Ct. App. 1988).Â  As such, alimony serves as a means of placing the supported
  spouse in a position as near as possible to the position he or she enjoyed
  during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  â€œHowever, â€˜[a]limony should not dissuade a
  spouse, to the extent possible, from becoming self-supporting.â€™â€Â  Davis v.
    Davis, 372 S.C. 64, 79, 641 S.E.2d 446, 453-54 (Ct. App. 2006)
  (quoting Rimer v. Rimer, 361 S.C. 521, 525, 605 S.E.2d 572, 574 (Ct.
  App. 2004)).Â  The ultimate alimony award, while based upon the reasonable needs
  of the wife, â€œshould not serve as a disincentive for her to make reasonable
  efforts to improve her employment potential or dissuade her, to the extent
  feasible, from becoming self-supporting.â€Â  Josey v. Josey, 291 S.C. 26,
  33, 351 S.E.2d 891, 896 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  â€œIt is the duty of the family
  court to make an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim is
  well founded.â€Â  Allen, 347 S.C. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424 (citing Woodward
    v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 217, 363 S.E.2d 413, 417 (Ct. App. 1987)).
South
  Carolina law provides the family court
  may grant alimony in such amounts and for such term as the judge considers
  appropriate under the circumstances.Â  Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 462,
  486 S.E.2d 516, 523 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Factors to be considered in making an
  alimony award include: (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the
  parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and
  earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the
  marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7)
  current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and
  nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital
  misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations;
  as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant. S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  Additionally, the amount received as a result of
  equitable distribution is also a factor to be considered in awarding alimony.Â  Josey,
  291 S.C. at 33, 351 S.E.2d at 895-96.Â  The weight accorded to each factor is
  within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  The family court has discretion to determine the amount of any
  alimony award.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-230(B)(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  
Where
  alimony is appropriate, South Carolina favors permanent periodic alimony over
  other statutory forms of alimony.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 95,
  545 S.E.2d 531, 535 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this preference, however, South Carolina recognizes rehabilitative alimony as an alternative in special
  circumstances.Â  â€œRehabilitative alimony may be awarded only upon a showing of
  special circumstances justifying a departure from the normal preference for
  permanent periodic support.â€Â  Jenkins, 345 S.C. at 95, 545 S.E.2d at
  535.Â  The purpose of rehabilitative alimony is to further the ability of a
  dependant spouse to become self-supporting following a divorce.Â  Id.
In
  the present case, the family court considered all of the pertinent statutory factors
  including the duration of the marriage and Husbandâ€™s conduct in determining
  whether to make an award of alimony.Â  Upon weighing the necessary factors as
  well as the equitable distribution award, the family court found that permanent
  periodic alimony was not appropriate in this case.Â  
Additionally,
  the court did not specifically find the need for rehabilitative alimony.Â 
  Instead, the court evaluated whether rehabilitative alimony, in a best case
  scenario, would be beneficial to Wife.Â  After reviewing the numbers and upon
  consideration of the tax consequences, the family court concluded that Wife was
  better off financially without an award of alimony.Â  While we would not condone
  the substitution of child support for alimony, we do not reach this question as
  we do not interpret the courtâ€™s best case scenario as being tantamount to a
  finding to award rehabilitative alimony.Â  Accordingly, the courtâ€™s alternative
  reasoning is merely dicta and is not dispositive of this appeal.Â  We interpret
  the courtâ€™s decision as denying any form of alimony after consideration of the
  various factors and record, especially in light of Wifeâ€™s age, education,
  employment history, and ability to work.Â  In her brief on appeal, Wife only
  claims that she is entitled to permanent periodic alimony.Â  Since Wife bases
  her alimony argument on the alleged errors of the court on the other grounds of
  appeal, as well as the courtâ€™s alleged error in that portion we find to be dicta,
  we find no abuse of discretion by the family court.Â  We further note that the
  court was never presented with any request, by virtue of the pleadings, or at
  trial, to award rehabilitative alimony. Thus, we find no abuse of discretion in
  the family courtâ€™s decision to deny Wife alimony.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the decision of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] According to Bradley, Husband and Wife borrowed approximately
  $41,000 and have paid back over $33,000.Â  
[2] Bradley is not a party to this litigation.Â  Our
  ruling on this issue is limited solely to the courtâ€™s equitable distribution
  analysis.Â  We express no opinion on Bradleyâ€™s right to assert a claim against
  Husband or Wife.
[3] Wife asserts all of these acts, except pavement of
  the driveway, occurred before marriage and suggests the property is thus
  nonmarital.Â  However, the court is not limited solely to acts occurring during
  marriage in its determination of the intent of the parties.
