THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Interest of James L., a Minor Under the Age of Seventeen, Appellant,
				v.
				The State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal
  From Colleton County
Gerald
  C. Smoak, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished
  Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-268
Submitted
  May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 16, 2008 
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, South Carolina Office of Appellate
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,
  Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney
  General Salley W. Elliott, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â   James L. (James) appeals the family
  courtâ€™s sentence of suspended
  commitment to the Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) and probation based on
  Jamesâ€™ convictions for third-degree arson and third-degree burglary.Â  James
  contends the family court erred when it failed to grant his motions for
  directed verdicts on these two charges.Â  We agree.
FACTS
On
  the afternoon of March 25, 2004, fifteen-year-old James and his thirteen-year-old
  friend, T.J., entered a vacant mobile home in Walterboro, South Carolina.Â 
  According to Jamesâ€™ statement to the police and his testimony at trial, he and
  T.J. entered the mobile home through the unlocked front door.Â  James testified
  they were not planning on stealing anything or damaging the mobile home.Â  After
  walking around the inside of the unoccupied home, they remained in the living
  room where they smoked several cigarettes. Â Once they finished smoking the
  cigarettes and the pack was empty, James set the empty carton on fire and threw
  it on the floor. Â He then proceeded to stomp out the remaining flames, and both
  boys exited the mobile home.Â  
T.J.
  also testified they entered through the unlocked front door of the mobile home,
  which was missing its doorknob. Â T.J. said after walking around the mobile
  home, they stopped in the living room where James proceeded to smoke two
  cigarettes.Â  Afterwards, James lit the pack on fire and threw it onto the floor
  near a mattress.Â  T.J. stated James asked him to urinate on the pack to put out
  the fire, but T.J. refused. Â James stomped the pack out with his feet, but T.J.
  said there was still â€œa little bit of ashes [lit] up.â€ 
After
  James and T.J. left the mobile home, the smoldering ashes caught the living
  room on fire, which ultimately resulted in the burning of the mobile home.Â  James
  was subsequently charged with third-degree arson and second-degree burglary.[1]Â  
During
  trial, the investigating detective testified there was no physical evidence to
  support the arson charge. Â The detective stated James intentionally set the
  fire, but he also stated James was negligent in setting the fire.Â  Further, when
  questioned, the detective admitted it was possible for James to have thought he
  extinguished the fire without realizing it was still smoldering.Â  
At the
  conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, Jamesâ€™ counsel made directed verdict motions on
  the arson and burglary charges, which the family court denied.Â  Jamesâ€™ counsel
  renewed these motions at the close of trial, which the family court again
  denied.Â  The family court held the State proved its case beyond a
  reasonable doubt, as James acted wrongfully and willfully when he lit the
  cigarette pack on fire and caused the burning of the trailer.Â  As such, James
  was sentenced to a suspended commitment to the DJJ and was also placed on probation.Â 
  This appeal follows.[2]Â  
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
On
  appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, this Court must view the evidence
  in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C.
  622, 633, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed
  verdict, the family court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of
  evidence, not its weight.Â  In the Interest of
    Cisco K., 332 S.C. 649, 652, 506 S.E.2d 536, 538 (Ct. App. 1998).
If
  there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably
  tending to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the denial of
  the directed verdict was proper.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653,
  572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a
  directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense
  charged. Â State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171
  (2003).Â 
  Similarly, the trial court should grant a directed verdict when the evidence
  merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Zeigler,
  364 S.C. 94, 102, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
James
  argues the family court erred in denying his motions for directed verdicts on
  the arson and burglary charges because the State presented no direct or
  substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove Jamesâ€™ guilt.Â  We
  agree. 
I.
  Arson in the Third Degree
Our arson
  statute provides in pertinent part that â€œa person who wilfully and maliciously
  . . . sets fire to, burns, or causes a burning which results in damage to a
  building or structure . . . is guilty of arson in the third degree . . . .â€
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-110(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  
The State must
  present evidence of the corpus delicti for an arson case to proceed to the jury.
  Â State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 381, 385, 468 S.E.2d 656, 658 (1996). Â In
  an arson case, the corpus delicti is comprised of (1) a burned building or
  other property, and (2) some criminal agency which caused the burning.Â  Id. at 384, 468 S.E.2d at 658.Â  â€œIn other words, the corpus delicti includes not
  only the fact of burning, but it must also appear that the burning was by the
  willful act of some person, and not as a result of a natural or accidental
  cause.â€ Id. at 384-85, 468 S.E.2d at 658 (internal quotations omitted). 
In this case,
  the State failed to present any evidence, either direct or circumstantial, that
  the burning of the mobile home was an intentional, willful, or malicious act.Â Â 
  Both Jamesâ€™ and T.J.â€™s testimony tend to prove James did not intend to burn the
  mobile home when he lit the cigarette pack on fire and threw it on the floor. Â Both
  testified James stomped on the pack more than once in an attempt to extinguish
  any remaining flames.Â  Further, James stated he did not see any ashes or
  smolder, but if he had, he would have stomped out the remaining flames.Â  James
  believed the fire was completely extinguished when they exited the home. 
During trial,
  the investigating detective admitted no physical evidence existed to support
  the arson charge. Â Further, the detective admitted it was possible for James to
  have thought he put the fire out without realizing it was still smoldering when
  he left the mobile home.Â  
Considering
  the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, there is no direct or
  substantial circumstantial evidence showing Jamesâ€™ actions rose to a level that
  would support the charge of arson.Â  While James may have been negligent in
  failing to extinguish the cigarette pack before leaving the mobile home, the
  State failed to present sufficient evidence he acted in a willful and
  intentional manner.Â  Consequently, the family court erred in denying Jamesâ€™
  motion for a directed verdict on the arson charge.
II.Â  Burglary in
  the Third Degree
South Carolinaâ€™s burglary statute provides a â€œperson is guilty of burglary in the third
  degree if the person enters a building without consent and with intent to
  commit a crime therein.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-313(A) (Supp. 2007). 
In this case,
  it is uncontroverted James entered the mobile home without the ownerâ€™s
  permission, as the owner testified she never gave James permission to go on the
  property.Â  Thus, the determinate factor is whether James entered the mobile
  home with the intent to commit a crime.Â  
â€œThere is no
  requirement that the intent element is satisfied only by proving an intent to
  commit the specific crime that is charged in the indictment as an aggravating
  circumstance.â€Â  Pinckney v. State, 368 S.C. 502, 505, 629 S.E.2d 367,
  369 (2006).Â  The only requirement is that the person has the intent to commit
  any crime at the time of entry. Â Id.Â  The personâ€™s actions after
  entering the dwelling can be evidence in determining whether the person had the
  intent to commit a crime at the time of entry.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339
  S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â  Further, to constitute burglary, it
  is not necessary the intended crime be committed or the person be convicted of
  the intended crime.Â  State v. Peterson, 336 S.C. 6, 7, 518 S.E.2d 277,
  278 (Ct. App. 1999).
In this case,
  the State argued James entered the mobile home with the intent to commit a
  crime. Â The State first contended James entered the mobile home with the intent
  to commit arson, as he wanted to burn the mobile home to conceal he had entered
  it without permission.Â  This assertion mirrors the juvenile petition, which
  stated the burglary charge was supported by Jamesâ€™ unlawful entry coupled with
  the intent to commit arson.Â  As explained above, the evidence does not support
  a charge of arson.Â  
The State
  further argued that based on Jamesâ€™ prior burglary of a neighborâ€™s storage
  shed,[3] the family court could infer intent to commit larceny on the day in question. Â However,
  the State failed to produce any evidence, either direct or circumstantial, that
  James stole any property or intended on that specific occasion to enter the
  mobile home for the purpose of stealing property.Â  Jamesâ€™ and T.J.â€™s testimony
  contradicts this assertion as well.Â  
Jamesâ€™ counsel
  claimed at the directed verdict stage that while the investigating officer
  argued Jamesâ€™ act of underage smoking was a crime, Jamesâ€™ entry into the mobile
  home with the intent to smoke cigarettes would not support a charge of third-degree
  burglary.Â  
While the sale
  or purchase of tobacco products to a minor is illegal, if a minor under the age
  of eighteen buys or possesses tobacco products, the minor commits only a non-criminal
  offense and is subject to a civil fine of twenty-five dollars.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§Â§ 16-17-500(A), (E)(1), (E)(2)Â  (Supp. 2007).Â  The statute specifically states
  that â€œa violation of this subsection is not a criminal or delinquent offense
  and no criminal or delinquent record may be maintained.â€Â  Â§ 16-17-500(E)(5).Â 
  Consequently, this argument is without merit. 
CONCLUSION
The State failed
  to present any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence to establish James
  was guilty of third-degree arson or third-degree burglary.Â  Without more than a
  mere suspicion of guilt, the family court erred in failing to grant Jamesâ€™
  motions for directed verdicts on the arson and burglary charges.
Therefore, the
  order of the family court isÂ Â Â  
REVERSED.[4]
SHORT,
  WILLIAMS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] James was initially
  charged with burglary in the second degree and arson in the third degree for
  the mobile home incident and burglary in the third degree for a separate
  incident.Â  The State moved to amend its petition from a charge of burglary in
  the second degree to burglary in the third degree, which the family court
  granted.Â  James pled guilty to the third-degree burglary charge stemming from
  the separate incident and requested a trial on the remaining two charges.Â  
[2] James appealed
  the family courtâ€™s ruling pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738
  (1967).Â  Jamesâ€™ appellate counsel filed a brief along with a petition to be
  relieved, stating her examination of the record indicated the appeal was
  without merit.Â  Following our Anders review, this Court ordered the
  parties to brief the following issue: Whether the family court properly denied
  Jamesâ€™ motions for directed verdicts on the charge of arson in the third degree
  and burglary in the third degree.Â  This issue is now our sole appellate
  consideration.
[3] The record
  fails to fully establish the details of the storage shed incident.Â  It appears
  from the record that James admitted to removing several dishes and appliances
  from a neighborâ€™s shed prior to this incident and selling them to another
  individual for five dollars per box.Â  James pled guilty to this burglary charge
  and does not appeal this ruling. 
[4] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Petitioner argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion for

  affirm[2] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: 
Issue 1: State v. Irick, 344 S.C. 460, 464, 545
  S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001) (holding an abuse of discretion
  occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support
  or are controlled by an error of law); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C.

  reversal); State v. Tanner, 299 S.C. 459, 462, 385 S.E.2d 832,
  834 (1989) (holding the denial of a motion for a continuance is within the
  sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed absent a clear
  showing of an abuse of discretion); State v. Lytchfield, 230 S.C.
  405, 409, 95 S.E.2d 857, 859, (1957) (â€œ[R]eversals of refusal of continuance
  are about as rare as the proverbial hensâ€™ teeth.â€).
Â Issue
  2: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2007) (categorizing trafficking of
  marijuana as a violent crime); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(A) (Supp. 2007) (â€œIf

  firearm . . . and is convicted of committing or attempting to commit a violent
  crime as defined in Section 16-1-60, he must be imprisoned five years, in
  addition to the punishment provided for the principal crime.â€); State v.
    Parris, 363 S.C. 477, 481, 611 S.E.2d 501, 502-03 (2005) (holding in
  reviewing a directed verdict
  motion, the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence,
  not its weight);Â  State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 102, 610 S.E.2d 859,

  an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€); State
    v. Brown, 360 S.C. 581, 586, 602 S.E.2d 392, 395 (2004) (holding a
  defendant is entitled to a directed verdict
  when the State fails to present evidence on a material
  element of the offense charged, and the evidence must be
  viewed in the light most favorable to the State).Â  Â Â 
AFFIRMED. Â 
HUFF,
  KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The Estate of
      George King by and through Margaret Coe King as the Duly Appointed Personal
      Representative, Respondent,
				v.
				Richland County and Prison Health Services, Inc., Defendants,
				of whom Prison
      Health Services, Inc. is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-274
Heard April 10, 2008 â€“ Filed May 21, 2008
DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Richard A. Harpootlian and Graham L. Newman, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
				J. Edward Bell, III, and C. Carter Elliott, Jr., both of Georgetown, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Prison
  Health Services, Inc. (Prison Health) appeals from two discovery orders.Â  We
  dismiss the appeal as interlocutory.
FACTS
On January 5, 2004, the Estate of George King (the
  Estate) brought claims for negligence and wrongful death against Richland County.Â  On February 28, 2005, the complaint was amended to include Prison Health
  as a defendant.Â  The complaint alleged Richland County and Prison Health failed
  to provide adequate medical care to King after he was injured while
  incarcerated at the Alvin S. Glenn Detention Center in Richland County, and
  King died as a result. Â At the time, Prison Health provided medical
  services for the Detention Center.
On September 26, 2005, the Estate sent Rule 30(b)(5)
  and 30(b)(6) deposition notices to Prison Health, including requests for the
  production of documents at the deposition.Â  Subsequently, Prison Health filed
  motions to quash portions of the deposition notices, and the Estate responded by
  filing a motion to compel Prison Health to produce the requested documents and
  answers. Â Following a hearing, Judge Reginald Lloyd denied Prison
  Healthâ€™s motions to quash, and granted the Estateâ€™s motion to compel on January
  31, 2006.
The Estate attempted to move forward with the
  depositions; however, the Estate contended the information Prison Health
  provided did not meet the requirements of Judge Lloydâ€™s order and subsequently
  filed a motion to enforce the courtâ€™s order.Â  On September 8, 2006, the matter
  was heard before Judge James R. Barber,[1] who requested the parties reach an agreement on the information to be provided
  by Prison Health; however, the parties were unable to agree.Â  Ultimately, Judge
  Barber issued an order granting the Estateâ€™s motion.Â  Prison Health responded
  with a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the order.Â  
On October 10, 2006, Judge Barber filed an amended order,
  as well as a qualified protective order.Â  The amended order required Prison
  Health to comply with Judge Lloydâ€™s initial order by providing all information
  and witnesses necessary to fully and completely respond to the Rule 30(b)(5)
  and 30(b)(6) deposition notices.Â  Additionally, the order required Prison
  Health to produce all materials by October 13, 2006.Â Â Â Â Â  
On October 20, 2006, Prison Health filed and served an
  amended notice of appeal.Â  Subsequently, the Estate responded by filing a motion
  to dismiss the appeal, which was denied with leave to argue the issue of appealability.
  Â In response, the parties filed briefs arguing both the issue of appealability
  as well as the merits of the appeal itself.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œThe right of appeal arises from and is controlled by
  statutory law.â€ Â Ex parte Capital U-Drive-It, Inc., 369 S.C. 1, 6,
  630 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2006).Â  â€œAn appeal ordinarily may be pursued only
  after a party has obtained a final judgment.â€ Â Id.; S.C.Code Ann. Â§
  14-3-330 (1976); Rule 72, SCRCP; Rule 201(a), SCACR.Â  â€œThe determination of whether a party may immediately appeal
  an order issued before or during trial is governed primarily by S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 14-3-330.â€Â  Ex parte Capital U-Drive-It, Inc., at 6, 630 S.E.2d
  at 467.Â  â€œAbsent a specialized statute, an order must fall into one of several
  categories set forth in Section 14-3-330 in order to be immediately
  appealable.â€Â  Id.Â  Courts in South Carolina have generally held that
  orders directing a party to participate in discovery are interlocutory and not
  directly appealable under section 14-3-330. Â See, e.g., Ex
    parte Whetstone, 289 S.C. 580, 580, 347 S.E.2d 881, 881 (1986); Patterson
      v. Specter Broadcasting, 287 S.C. 249, 335 S.E.2d 803 (1985); Lowndes
        Products, Inc. v. Brower, 262 S.C. 431, 205 S.E.2d 184 (1974).
In an
  analogous case involving privileged information, the supreme court held a discovery
  order was not immediately appealable because â€œan order compelling discovery
  does not ordinarily involve the merits of the case.â€ Tucker v. Honda of South Carolina Mfg., Inc., 354 S.C. 574, 577, 582 S.E.2d 405, 406 (2003).Â  Furthermore,
  the court explained â€œ[s]ince a contempt order is final in
  nature, an order compelling discovery may be appealed
  only after the trial court holds a party in contempt.â€ Id. at 577, 583 S.E.2d at 406-07.Â  â€œThus, a party may comply with the
  order and waive any right to challenge it on appeal or refuse to comply with
  the order, be cited for contempt, and appeal.â€Â  Id. at 577, 582 S.E.2d
  at 407.Â  
Notwithstanding
  the holdings of the cases above, Prison Health argues the order is appealable
  because 1) it requires the production of privileged and confidential material
  and 2) compliance with the order would prevent an appeal of the issues.Â  As
  explained in the Tucker case, Prison Health may appeal if it is
  held in contempt.Â  Furthermore, section 14-3-330(2)(a), which applies to orders
  affecting substantial rights which â€œin effect determine[] the action and
  prevent[] a judgment from which an appeal might be taken or discontinues the
  action,â€ does not apply to the present case. (emphasis added).Â  The limited civil
  cases in which section 14-3-330(2)(a) has been applied to discovery orders are
  distinguishable because in those cases the subject matter of the entire
  litigation was the protection of information; therefore, the discovery orders
  compelling the production of the information effectively determined the actions
  and ended the litigation as moot.Â  See, e.g., Knight Pub. Co.
    v. Univ. of South Carolina, 295 S.C. 31, 32, 367 S.E.2d 20, 21 (1988)
  (â€œThe appealed order allows discovery of documents that respondents ultimately
  seek disclosed as the subject of these FOIA actions. This order is directly
  appealable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2)(a) (1976) because it in effect
  determines the action and prevents an appealable judgment.â€), overruled on
  other grounds, Simpson v. Sanders, 314 S.C. 413, 445 S.E.2d 93 (1994).Â  Â 
The
  discovery order in the instant case, however, does not effectively meet the
  requirements for immediate appealability.Â  The Estateâ€™s causes of action for
  negligence and wrongful death are not so intimately associated with the
  production of the requested documents that the order itself determines the
  subject matter of the action.Â  Indeed, regardless of whether the documents are
  actually produced, the Estateâ€™s action would proceed to further stages of the
  litigation. Therefore, section 14-3-330(2)(a) does not provide for immediate
  appeal of the order.Â  Prison Healthâ€™s appeal is interlocutory and premature.Â 
  Since Prison Health has not refused to comply with the order and has not been
  found in contempt, the discovery order remains interlocutory and unappealable.Â  
Furthermore,
  the order about which Prison Health complains affords a mechanism by which
  Prison Health can seek additional protection for information believed to be
  protected under HIPPA or more stringent state law.Â  Judge Barberâ€™s order
  specifically states that all materials covered by HIPPA â€œshall be produced
  without redaction unless required by HIPPA or a state statute which is more
  stringent than HIPPA.â€Â  Moreover, the order provides an additional opportunity
  to seek a subsequent court order if a determination is made that the
  information requested is additionally protected by state law.Â  Further, in the
  event Prison Health refuses to turn over information it deems protected, it
  will have the opportunity to show cause before the trial court why it is not in
  contempt.Â  Therefore, the discovery order at issue herein is not immediately appealable.[2]
Finally,
  any assertion that Judge Barber improperly enforced or altered Judge Lloydâ€™s
  order, or that a final order had not yet been issued by Judge Lloyd, does not
  convert this matter from an interlocutory order to a final order.
Accordingly,
  Prison Healthâ€™s appeal is interlocutory and hereby
DISMISSED.
HEARN,
  C.J., PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] In the time between Judge Lloydâ€™s initial order and
  the Estateâ€™s motion, Judge Lloyd had left the bench.Â  
[2] In McGee v. Bruce Hospital System, 312 S.C. 58,
  439 S.E.2d 257 (1993), the Supreme Court reviewed on appeal a discovery order
  pertaining to the Peer Review Statute and that decision was relied upon by a
  panel of this court in Wieters v. Bon-Secours-St. Francis Xavier Hosp., Inc.,
  Op. No. 4374 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 23, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. at 16
  at 75).Â  However, we find McGee distinguishable since that case was
  being reviewed by the Supreme Court pursuant to a writ of certiorari and any
  issue of the interlocutory nature of the order was not addressed.Â  Moreover, the
  discovery orders at issue in McGee and Wieters were unlike the
  order in the case sub judice which clearly allowed for the withholding of HIPPA
  information further protected by state law and additionally provided for
  further court review if necessary to obtain such information.Â  The open-ended
  nature of the order herein clearly makes it interlocutory.

				v.
				Christine Grove, Appellant,
			
		
	


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-278
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed May 27, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Asst. Deputy Atty. Gen. Salley W. Elliot, all of
  Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Christine Grove appeals her
  convictions for possession with intent to distribute marijuana and cocaine.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS
Deputy Sean Seebode observed a car backing out of a
  power substation at 3:30 a.m. on December 14, 2005.Â  When he pulled in to
  investigate, he observed two women in the vehicle: Grove, and the driver Bianca
  Ford.Â  Seebode inquired as to their reason for being at the substation so early
  in the morning, and the two replied they had stopped so Grove could go to the
  bathroom in the neighboring woods.Â  Seebode checked Fordâ€™s driverâ€™s license and
  called in Groveâ€™s name and birthdate, as she did not have identification on her
  person.Â  While Seebode checked the identifications, Corporal Jennifer Flowers
  joined him at the scene.Â  Both Seebode and Flowers asked for permission to
  search the vehicle, and Ford verbally consented on each occasion.Â  
Once consent was
  given, Ford and Grove were then directed to exit the vehicle, and Flowers
  conducted an initial pat down.Â  Flowersâ€™ subsequent search of the vehicle
  revealed a film canister containing three individually-wrapped bags of
  marijuana and six bags of cocaine located under the passenger seat, and five
  bags of marijuana beside the driverâ€™s seat. Â Grove and Ford were placed under
  arrest and taken into custody.Â  Thereafter, Flowers conducted a more thorough pat
  down and search incident to arrest of both women, finding $634 in cash on Grove.[1] 
Grove was indicted
  for possession with intent to distribute marijuana and cocaine, and a jury trial
  was held.Â  After the State presented its case, Grove moved for a directed
  verdict, contending the State failed to show she had constructive possession of
  the drugs since she was a passenger in a car that belonged to Ford.Â  This
  motion was denied.Â  Grove presented no evidence in her defense and renewed her
  motion for directed verdict at the close of the case.Â  That motion was denied,
  and the jury found Grove guilty of possession with intent to distribute cocaine
  and marijuana.Â  She was sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment.Â  This appeal
  followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When
  considering a motion for directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the
  existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Weston,
  367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006).Â  A defendant is entitled to a
  directed verdict when the State fails to present evidence of the offense
  charged.Â  Id.Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, an
  appellate court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light
  most favorable to the State.Â  Id.Â  If there is any direct evidence or
  any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt
  of the accused, the appellate court must find the case was properly submitted
  to the jury.Â  Id. at 292-93, 625 S.E.2d at 648.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Grove
  argues the trial court erred in denying her motion for directed verdict as the State
  failed to prove she had possession of the cocaine and marijuana that was found
  in the vehicle owned by her co-defendant.Â  We disagree.
A
  conviction of possession requires proof of actual or constructive possession of
  an illegal substance and knowledge of its presence.Â  State v. Muhammed,
  338 S.C. 22, 26, 524 S.E.2d 637, 639 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  To establish
  constructive possession, the State must prove the defendant had dominion and
  control, or the right to exercise dominion and control, over an illegal
  substance.Â  State v. Heath, 370 S.C. 326, 329, 635 S.E.2d 18, 19
  (2006).Â  This can be shown through circumstantial or direct evidence.Â  Id.Â  Here, a film canister containing individual bags of cocaine and marijuana was
  found just under the front lip of the passenger seat, an area easily accessible
  to Grove.Â  Additionally, a search of Groveâ€™s person revealed $634 in cash, the
  existence of which, Flowers testified, when combined with individually packaged
  drugs, was often a good indication of drug distribution activity.Â  Furthermore,
  Grove was a close acquaintance of the owner of the vehicle, Ford, who testified
  the two had attended a bowling party and smoked marijuana earlier in the
  evening.
Viewing
  these facts in the light most favorable to the State, as we must under our
  standard of review, we find there exists sufficient evidence in the record to
  support the trial judgeâ€™s decision to submit the issue of actual or
  constructive possession to the jury.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial
  court is 
AFFIRMED.[2]
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] Ford testified that the money was actually hers and
  Grove was just holding it for her.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this action for death benefits, the circuit court affirmed the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commissionâ€™s (Commissionâ€™s) denial of benefits for the death of
  Keith Davideit.Â  Kevin Davideit appeals on behalf of the decedent.Â  We affirm.Â 
  Â Â 
FACTS
When he died, Keith Davideit was a forty-four-year-old employee of
  ScanSource.Â  Davideit had a seizure disorder that he managed by taking Dilantin.Â 
  He suffered only two seizures in thirteen years.Â  Sometime in the afternoon of
  May 9, 2003, Davideit left his work station and went to the menâ€™s restroom.Â 
  His co-workers later found him there, dead.Â  He was lying on his back in a
  stall with his pants around his knees, as if he had been sitting on the toilet
  and had fallen off.Â  A waste can partially covered his head, and he had
  aspirated some of the waste canâ€™s plastic liner.Â  A co-worker â€œhad to pull
  several timesâ€ to remove the plastic liner from Davideitâ€™s mouth.Â  
Dr. Michael Ward performed an autopsy at the request of the
  coroner and the medical examinerâ€™s office.Â  The autopsy revealed
  atherosclerotic coronary vascular disease with seventy to seventy-five percent
  stenosis of the vessel lumen and acute pulmonary vascular congestion.[1] Â Dr. Ward found Davideitâ€™s somewhat
  enlarged heart (mild cardiomegaly) and his aspiration of the plastic liner
  contributed to his death. Â 
Dr. Ward testified he believed Davideit died from a heart attack
  caused by atherosclerotic coronary artery disease rather than from
  asphyxiation.Â  Dr. Ward prepared paraffin blocks during the autopsy, but they
  did not confirm asphyxiation as the cause of death.Â  He found mild pulmonary
  vascular congestion, meaning blood was backed up in the lungâ€™s blood vessels
  because the left side of the heart was not functioning properly near death.Â  Dr.
  Ward testified this condition corresponds directly with a heart attack but only
  indirectly with asphyxiation. Â Dr. Ward conceded Davideit may have suffered a
  seizure as well as a heart attack.Â  The postmortem toxicology report found no
  Dilantin in his system.Â  Dr. Ward believed Davideit did not die immediately
  upon falling to the floor; rather, he continued breathing at least long enough
  to inhale the plastic liner.Â  However, Dr. Ward opined that Davideit would have
  died regardless of whether the plastic liner was in his throat.Â  Â Â
